context: The purpose of GDPR is to lay down rules relating to the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and rules relating to the free movement of personal data.
question: What is the purpose of GDPR? reference Article 1 Subject-matter and objectives, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: The purpose of GDPR is to lay down rules relating to the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and rules relating to the free movement of personal data.

context: GDPR applies to the processing of personal data wholly or partly by automated means and to the processing other than by automated means of personal data which form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system.
question: What is the scope of GDPR? reference Article 2 Material scope, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: GDPR applies to the processing of personal data wholly or partly by automated means and to the processing other than by automated means of personal data which form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system.

context: GDPR applies to the processing of personal data in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the Union, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not.
question: What is the territorial scope of GDPR? reference Article 3 Territorial scope, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: GDPR applies to the processing of personal data in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the Union, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not.

context: Personal data means any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person (‘data subject’); an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person.
question: What is the definition of personal data according to GDPR? reference Article 4 Definitions, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: Personal data means any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person (‘data subject’); an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person.

context: For the purposes of this Regulation, 'group of undertakings' means a controlling undertaking and its controlled undertakings.
question: What is the definition of 'group of undertakings' according to GDPR? reference Article 4 Definitions, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: For the purposes of this Regulation, 'group of undertakings' means a controlling undertaking and its controlled undertakings.

context: The six principles relating to processing of personal data according to GDPR are: lawfulness, fairness and transparency; purpose limitation; data minimisation; accuracy; storage limitation; and integrity and confidentiality.
question: What are the six principles relating to processing of personal data according to GDPR? reference Article 5 Principles relating to processing of personal data, Chapter 2 Principles

text: The six principles relating to processing of personal data according to GDPR are: lawfulness, fairness and transparency; purpose limitation; data minimisation; accuracy; storage limitation; and integrity and confidentiality.

context: Processing of personal data is considered lawful if at least one of the following applies: (a) the data subject has given consent to the processing of his or her personal data for one or more specific purposes; (b) processing is necessary for the performance of a contract to which the data subject is party or in order to take steps at the request of the data subject prior to entering into a contract; (c) processing is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject; (d) processing is necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the data subject or of another natural person; (e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller; (f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party, except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject which require protection of personal data, in particular where the data subject is a child.
question: Under what circumstances is processing of personal data considered lawful? reference Article 6 Lawfulness of processing, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Processing of personal data is considered lawful if at least one of the following applies: (a) the data subject has given consent to the processing of his or her personal data for one or more specific purposes; (b) processing is necessary for the performance of a contract to which the data subject is party or in order to take steps at the request of the data subject prior to entering into a contract; (c) processing is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject; (d) processing is necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the data subject or of another natural person; (e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller; (f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party, except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject which require protection of personal data, in particular where the data subject is a child.

context: Article 7 of GDPR outlines the conditions for obtaining valid consent from a data subject for the processing of their personal data.
question: What is the purpose of Article 7 of GDPR? reference Article 7 Conditions for consent, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Article 7 of GDPR outlines the conditions for obtaining valid consent from a data subject for the processing of their personal data.

context: If point (a) of Article 6(1) applies and the information society services are offered directly to a child, the processing of personal data of a child shall be lawful if the child is at least 16 years old. If the child is below 16 years old, such processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that consent is given or authorized by the holder of parental responsibility over the child. Member States may provide by law for a lower age for those purposes provided that such lower age is not below 13 years.
question: What is the age limit for a child to give consent for processing their personal data in relation to information society services? reference Article 8 Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services, Chapter 2 Principles

text: If point (a) of Article 6(1) applies and the information society services are offered directly to a child, the processing of personal data of a child shall be lawful if the child is at least 16 years old. If the child is below 16 years old, such processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that consent is given or authorized by the holder of parental responsibility over the child. Member States may provide by law for a lower age for those purposes provided that such lower age is not below 13 years.

context: Processing of personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation shall be prohibited.
question: What types of personal data processing are prohibited by GDPR? reference Article 9 Processing of special categories of personal data, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Processing of personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic data, biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person, data concerning health or data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation shall be prohibited.

context: Article 11 of GDPR deals with processing of personal data that does not require identification of the data subject by the controller.
question: What is the purpose of Article 11 of GDPR? reference Article 11 Processing which does not require identification, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Article 11 of GDPR deals with processing of personal data that does not require identification of the data subject by the controller.

context: Article 12 of GDPR aims to ensure transparent information, communication, and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject.
question: What is the purpose of Article 12 of GDPR? reference Article 12 Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: Article 12 of GDPR aims to ensure transparent information, communication, and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject.

context: The controller must provide the data subject with the identity and contact details of the controller, the purposes of the processing, the legal basis for the processing, the recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data, and whether the controller intends to transfer personal data to a third country or international organization.
question: What information must a controller provide to a data subject when collecting personal data? reference Article 13 Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller must provide the data subject with the identity and contact details of the controller, the purposes of the processing, the legal basis for the processing, the recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data, and whether the controller intends to transfer personal data to a third country or international organization.

context: The controller must provide the data subject with the identity and contact details of the controller and, where applicable, of the controller's representative; the contact details of the data protection officer, where applicable; the purposes of the processing for which the personal data are intended as well as the legal basis for the processing; the categories of personal data concerned; the recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data, if any; where applicable, that the controller intends to transfer personal data to a recipient in a third country or international organisation and the existence or absence of an adequacy decision by the Commission, or in the case of transfers referred to in Article 46 or 47, or the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), reference to the appropriate or suitable safeguards and the means to obtain a copy of them or where they have been made available.
question: What information must a controller provide to a data subject if personal data have not been obtained from the data subject? reference Article 14 Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller must provide the data subject with the identity and contact details of the controller and, where applicable, of the controller's representative; the contact details of the data protection officer, where applicable; the purposes of the processing for which the personal data are intended as well as the legal basis for the processing; the categories of personal data concerned; the recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data, if any; where applicable, that the controller intends to transfer personal data to a recipient in a third country or international organisation and the existence or absence of an adequacy decision by the Commission, or in the case of transfers referred to in Article 46 or 47, or the second subparagraph of Article 49(1), reference to the appropriate or suitable safeguards and the means to obtain a copy of them or where they have been made available.

context: Article 15 of GDPR outlines the right of access by the data subject.
question: What is the purpose of Article 15 of GDPR? reference Article 15 Right of access by the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: Article 15 of GDPR outlines the right of access by the data subject.

context: The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller without undue delay the rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning him or her.
question: What is the right granted to the data subject under Article 16 of GDPR? reference Article 16 Right to rectification, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller without undue delay the rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning him or her.

context: The right to erasure, also known as the right to be forgotten, is the right of the data subject to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her without undue delay.
question: What is the right to erasure? reference Article 17 Right to erasure (‘right to be forgotten’), Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The right to erasure, also known as the right to be forgotten, is the right of the data subject to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her without undue delay.

context: Article 18 of GDPR provides the data subject with the right to obtain from the controller restriction of processing in certain circumstances.
question: What is the purpose of Article 18 of GDPR? reference Article 18 Right to restriction of processing, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: Article 18 of GDPR provides the data subject with the right to obtain from the controller restriction of processing in certain circumstances.

context: Article 19 of GDPR outlines the notification obligation of the controller regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing.
question: What is the purpose of Article 19 of GDPR? reference Article 19 Notification obligation regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: Article 19 of GDPR outlines the notification obligation of the controller regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing.

context: The right to data portability is the right of the data subject to receive the personal data concerning him or her, which he or she has provided to a controller, in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format and have the right to transmit those data to another controller without hindrance from the controller to which the personal data have been provided.
question: What is the right to data portability? reference Article 20 Right to data portability, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The right to data portability is the right of the data subject to receive the personal data concerning him or her, which he or she has provided to a controller, in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format and have the right to transmit those data to another controller without hindrance from the controller to which the personal data have been provided.

context: The data subject shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to his or her particular situation, at any time to processing of personal data concerning him or her which is based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including profiling based on those provisions.
question: What is the right to object according to GDPR? reference Article 21 Right to object, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The data subject shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to his or her particular situation, at any time to processing of personal data concerning him or her which is based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including profiling based on those provisions.

context: Article 22 of GDPR is about automated individual decision-making, including profiling, and it aims to protect the data subject's rights and freedoms.
question: What is the purpose of Article 22 of GDPR? reference Article 22 Automated individual decision-making, including profiling, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: Article 22 of GDPR is about automated individual decision-making, including profiling, and it aims to protect the data subject's rights and freedoms.

context: The purpose of Article 23 of GDPR is to allow Union or Member State law to restrict the scope of the obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34, as well as Article 5 in so far as its provisions correspond to the rights and obligations provided for in Articles 12 to 22.
question: What is the purpose of Article 23 of GDPR? reference Article 23 Restrictions, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The purpose of Article 23 of GDPR is to allow Union or Member State law to restrict the scope of the obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34, as well as Article 5 in so far as its provisions correspond to the rights and obligations provided for in Articles 12 to 22.

context: The controller shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure and to be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with this Regulation.
question: What is the responsibility of the controller according to Article 24 of GDPR? reference Article 24 Responsibility of the controller, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure and to be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with this Regulation.

context: The purpose of Article 25 of GDPR is to ensure data protection by design and by default.
question: What is the purpose of Article 25 of GDPR? reference Article 25 Data protection by design and by default, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The purpose of Article 25 of GDPR is to ensure data protection by design and by default.

context: Where two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes and means of processing, they shall be joint controllers.
question: What is the definition of joint controllers according to GDPR? reference Article 26 Joint controllers, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Where two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes and means of processing, they shall be joint controllers.

context: The purpose of Article 27 of GDPR is to require controllers or processors not established in the Union to designate a representative in the Union.
question: What is the purpose of Article 27 of GDPR? reference Article 27 Representatives of controllers or processors not established in the Union, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The purpose of Article 27 of GDPR is to require controllers or processors not established in the Union to designate a representative in the Union.

context: Article 28 of GDPR outlines the requirements for data processors who process personal data on behalf of a controller. It aims to ensure that processors implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect the rights of data subjects.
question: What is the purpose of Article 28 of GDPR? reference Article 28 Processor, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Article 28 of GDPR outlines the requirements for data processors who process personal data on behalf of a controller. It aims to ensure that processors implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect the rights of data subjects.

context: The processor and any person acting under the authority of the controller or of the processor, who has access to personal data, shall not process those data except on instructions from the controller, unless required to do so by Union or Member State law.
question: Who is allowed to process personal data under the GDPR? reference Article 29 Processing under the authority of the controller or processor, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The processor and any person acting under the authority of the controller or of the processor, who has access to personal data, shall not process those data except on instructions from the controller, unless required to do so by Union or Member State law.

context: The purpose of maintaining a record of processing activities is to contain information about the controller and its representative, the purposes of processing, categories of data subjects and personal data, recipients of personal data, transfers of personal data, time limits for erasure of data, and technical and organizational security measures.
question: What is the purpose of maintaining a record of processing activities? reference Article 30 Records of processing activities, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The purpose of maintaining a record of processing activities is to contain information about the controller and its representative, the purposes of processing, categories of data subjects and personal data, recipients of personal data, transfers of personal data, time limits for erasure of data, and technical and organizational security measures.

context: The controller and the processor and, where applicable, their representatives.
question: Who is required to cooperate with the supervisory authority? reference Article 31 Cooperation with the supervisory authority, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller and the processor and, where applicable, their representatives.

context: The purpose of Article 32 of GDPR is to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk of varying likelihood and severity for the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
question: What is the purpose of Article 32 of GDPR? reference Article 32 Security of processing, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The purpose of Article 32 of GDPR is to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk of varying likelihood and severity for the rights and freedoms of natural persons.

context: The controller shall without undue delay and, where feasible, not later than 72 hours after having become aware of it, notify the personal data breach to the supervisory authority.
question: What is the time limit for notifying the supervisory authority of a personal data breach? reference Article 33 Notification of a personal data breach to the supervisory authority, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller shall without undue delay and, where feasible, not later than 72 hours after having become aware of it, notify the personal data breach to the supervisory authority.

context: When the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
question: When is a controller required to communicate a personal data breach to the data subject? reference Article 34 Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: When the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.

context: A data protection impact assessment is required where a type of processing in particular using new technologies, and taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing, is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
question: When is a data protection impact assessment required? reference Article 35 Data protection impact assessment, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: A data protection impact assessment is required where a type of processing in particular using new technologies, and taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing, is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons.

context: The controller shall consult the supervisory authority prior to processing where a data protection impact assessment under Article 35 indicates that the processing would result in a high risk in the absence of measures taken by the controller to mitigate the risk.
question: When is a controller required to consult the supervisory authority prior to processing? reference Article 36 Prior consultation, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller shall consult the supervisory authority prior to processing where a data protection impact assessment under Article 35 indicates that the processing would result in a high risk in the absence of measures taken by the controller to mitigate the risk.

context: A data protection officer is required to be designated when the processing is carried out by a public authority or body, except for courts acting in their judicial capacity; the core activities of the controller or the processor consist of processing operations which, by virtue of their nature, their scope and/or their purposes, require regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale; or the core activities of the controller or the processor consist of processing on a large scale of special categories of data pursuant to Article 9 and personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences referred to in Article 10.
question: When is a data protection officer required to be designated? reference Article 37 Designation of the data protection officer, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: A data protection officer is required to be designated when the processing is carried out by a public authority or body, except for courts acting in their judicial capacity; the core activities of the controller or the processor consist of processing operations which, by virtue of their nature, their scope and/or their purposes, require regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale; or the core activities of the controller or the processor consist of processing on a large scale of special categories of data pursuant to Article 9 and personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences referred to in Article 10.

context: The data protection officer shall have at least the following tasks: to inform and advise the controller or the processor and the employees who carry out processing of their obligations pursuant to this Regulation and to other Union or Member State data protection provisions; to monitor compliance with this Regulation, with other Union or Member State data protection provisions and with the policies of the controller or processor in relation to the protection of personal data, including the assignment of responsibilities, awareness-raising and training of staff involved in processing operations, and the related audits; to provide advice where requested as regards the data protection impact assessment and monitor its performance pursuant to Article 35; to cooperate with the supervisory authority; to act as the contact point for the supervisory authority on issues relating to processing, including the prior consultation referred to in Article 36, and to consult, where appropriate, with regard to any other matter.
question: What are the tasks of the data protection officer according to GDPR? reference Article 39 Tasks of the data protection officer, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The data protection officer shall have at least the following tasks: to inform and advise the controller or the processor and the employees who carry out processing of their obligations pursuant to this Regulation and to other Union or Member State data protection provisions; to monitor compliance with this Regulation, with other Union or Member State data protection provisions and with the policies of the controller or processor in relation to the protection of personal data, including the assignment of responsibilities, awareness-raising and training of staff involved in processing operations, and the related audits; to provide advice where requested as regards the data protection impact assessment and monitor its performance pursuant to Article 35; to cooperate with the supervisory authority; to act as the contact point for the supervisory authority on issues relating to processing, including the prior consultation referred to in Article 36, and to consult, where appropriate, with regard to any other matter.

context: The controller and the processor are responsible for ensuring that the data protection officer is involved in all issues related to the protection of personal data.
question: Who is responsible for ensuring that the data protection officer is involved in all issues related to the protection of personal data? reference Article 38 Position of the data protection officer, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller and the processor are responsible for ensuring that the data protection officer is involved in all issues related to the protection of personal data.

context: Codes of conduct are intended to contribute to the proper application of GDPR, taking account of the specific features of the various processing sectors and the specific needs of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises.
question: What is the purpose of codes of conduct according to GDPR? reference Article 40 Codes of conduct, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Codes of conduct are intended to contribute to the proper application of GDPR, taking account of the specific features of the various processing sectors and the specific needs of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises.

context: The purpose of Article 41 of GDPR is to establish the conditions for monitoring compliance with a code of conduct.
question: What is the purpose of Article 41 of GDPR? reference Article 41 Monitoring of approved codes of conduct, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The purpose of Article 41 of GDPR is to establish the conditions for monitoring compliance with a code of conduct.

context: The purpose of data protection certification mechanisms and seals is to demonstrate compliance with GDPR of processing operations by controllers and processors.
question: What is the purpose of data protection certification mechanisms and seals? reference Article 42 Certification, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The purpose of data protection certification mechanisms and seals is to demonstrate compliance with GDPR of processing operations by controllers and processors.

context: Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures based on Article 6(1) shall be carried out only under the control of official authority or when the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.
question: Under what circumstances can personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences be processed? reference Article 10 Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures based on Article 6(1) shall be carried out only under the control of official authority or when the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.

context: Personal data can only be transferred to a third country or international organization if the conditions laid down in Chapter 5 of the GDPR are complied with by the controller and processor.
question: Under what conditions can personal data be transferred to a third country or international organization? reference Article 44 General principle for transfers, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: Personal data can only be transferred to a third country or international organization if the conditions laid down in Chapter 5 of the GDPR are complied with by the controller and processor.

context: Certification bodies which have an appropriate level of expertise in relation to data protection shall issue and renew certification.
question: What are certification bodies responsible for under GDPR? reference Article 43 Certification bodies, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Certification bodies which have an appropriate level of expertise in relation to data protection shall issue and renew certification.

context: Personal data can be transferred to a third country or international organization when the Commission has decided that the third country, a territory or one or more specified sectors within that third country, or the international organization in question ensures an adequate level of protection.
question: Under what circumstances can personal data be transferred to a third country or international organization? reference Article 45 Transfers on the basis of an adequacy decision, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: Personal data can be transferred to a third country or international organization when the Commission has decided that the third country, a territory or one or more specified sectors within that third country, or the international organization in question ensures an adequate level of protection.

context: A controller or processor may transfer personal data to a third country or an international organisation only if the controller or processor has provided appropriate safeguards, and on condition that enforceable data subject rights and effective legal remedies for data subjects are available.
question: Under what conditions can a controller or processor transfer personal data to a third country or international organization? reference Article 46 Transfers subject to appropriate safeguards, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: A controller or processor may transfer personal data to a third country or an international organisation only if the controller or processor has provided appropriate safeguards, and on condition that enforceable data subject rights and effective legal remedies for data subjects are available.

context: A controller or processor can transfer or disclose personal data based on a judgment of a court or tribunal or decision of an administrative authority of a third country only if it is based on an international agreement, such as a mutual legal assistance treaty, in force between the requesting third country and the Union or a Member State.
question: Under what circumstances can a controller or processor transfer or disclose personal data based on a judgment of a court or tribunal or decision of an administrative authority of a third country? reference Article 48 Transfers or disclosures not authorised by Union law, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: A controller or processor can transfer or disclose personal data based on a judgment of a court or tribunal or decision of an administrative authority of a third country only if it is based on an international agreement, such as a mutual legal assistance treaty, in force between the requesting third country and the Union or a Member State.

context: Article 47 of GDPR outlines the requirements for binding corporate rules and specifies the information that must be included in them.
question: What is the purpose of Article 47 of GDPR? reference Article 47 Binding corporate rules, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: Article 47 of GDPR outlines the requirements for binding corporate rules and specifies the information that must be included in them.

context: Personal data can be transferred to a third country or international organization in the absence of an adequacy decision or appropriate safeguards only if the data subject has explicitly consented to the proposed transfer, the transfer is necessary for the performance of a contract between the data subject and the controller, the transfer is necessary for the conclusion or performance of a contract concluded in the interest of the data subject between the controller and another natural or legal person, the transfer is necessary for important reasons of public interest, the transfer is necessary for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims, the transfer is necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the data subject or of other persons, or the transfer is made from a register which according to Union or Member State law is intended to provide information to the public and which is open to consultation either by the public in general or by any person who can demonstrate a legitimate interest.
question: Under what conditions can personal data be transferred to a third country or international organization in the absence of an adequacy decision or appropriate safeguards? reference Article 49 Derogations for specific situations, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: Personal data can be transferred to a third country or international organization in the absence of an adequacy decision or appropriate safeguards only if the data subject has explicitly consented to the proposed transfer, the transfer is necessary for the performance of a contract between the data subject and the controller, the transfer is necessary for the conclusion or performance of a contract concluded in the interest of the data subject between the controller and another natural or legal person, the transfer is necessary for important reasons of public interest, the transfer is necessary for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims, the transfer is necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the data subject or of other persons, or the transfer is made from a register which according to Union or Member State law is intended to provide information to the public and which is open to consultation either by the public in general or by any person who can demonstrate a legitimate interest.

context: The purpose of Article 50 of GDPR is to establish international cooperation mechanisms to facilitate the effective enforcement of legislation for the protection of personal data.
question: What is the purpose of Article 50 of GDPR? reference Article 50 International cooperation for the protection of personal data, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: The purpose of Article 50 of GDPR is to establish international cooperation mechanisms to facilitate the effective enforcement of legislation for the protection of personal data.

context: The purpose of the supervisory authority is to monitor the application of GDPR and protect the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons in relation to processing and to facilitate the free flow of personal data within the Union.
question: What is the purpose of the supervisory authority? reference Article 51 Supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: The purpose of the supervisory authority is to monitor the application of GDPR and protect the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons in relation to processing and to facilitate the free flow of personal data within the Union.

context: Each supervisory authority shall act with complete independence in performing its tasks and exercising its powers in accordance with this Regulation.
question: What is the requirement for each supervisory authority in performing its tasks and exercising its powers? reference Article 52 Independence, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Each supervisory authority shall act with complete independence in performing its tasks and exercising its powers in accordance with this Regulation.

context: Each member of the supervisory authority can be appointed by means of a transparent procedure by their parliament, their government, their head of State, or an independent body entrusted with the appointment under Member State law.
question: Who can appoint members of the supervisory authority? reference Article 53 General conditions for the members of the supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Each member of the supervisory authority can be appointed by means of a transparent procedure by their parliament, their government, their head of State, or an independent body entrusted with the appointment under Member State law.

context: Article 54 of GDPR specifies the rules on the establishment of the supervisory authority.
question: What does Article 54 of GDPR specify? reference Article 54 Rules on the establishment of the supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Article 54 of GDPR specifies the rules on the establishment of the supervisory authority.

context: Each supervisory authority shall be competent for the performance of the tasks assigned to and the exercise of the powers conferred on it in accordance with this Regulation on the territory of its own Member State.
question: What is the scope of competence of each supervisory authority? reference Article 55 Competence, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Each supervisory authority shall be competent for the performance of the tasks assigned to and the exercise of the powers conferred on it in accordance with this Regulation on the territory of its own Member State.

context: The supervisory authority of the main establishment or of the single establishment of the controller or processor.
question: Which supervisory authority is competent to act as lead supervisory authority for cross-border processing? reference Article 56 Competence of the lead supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: The supervisory authority of the main establishment or of the single establishment of the controller or processor.

context: Each supervisory authority shall monitor and enforce the application of GDPR, promote public awareness and understanding of the risks, rules, safeguards, and rights in relation to processing, advise the national parliament, the government, and other institutions and bodies on legislative and administrative measures relating to the protection of natural persons' rights and freedoms with regard to processing, promote the awareness of controllers and processors of their obligations under GDPR, provide information to any data subject concerning the exercise of their rights under GDPR, handle complaints lodged by a data subject, or by a body, organization, or association in accordance with Article 80, and investigate, to the extent appropriate, the subject matter of the complaint text: Processing of prohibited personal data is allowed if the data subject has given explicit consent, processing is necessary for carrying out obligations and exercising specific rights of the controller or of the data subject in the field of employment and social security and social protection law, processing is necessary to protect the vital interests of the data subject or of another natural person, processing is carried out in the course of legitimate activities with appropriate safeguards by a foundation, association or any other not-for-profit body with a political, philosophical, religious or trade union aim, processing relates to personal data which are manifestly made public by the data subject, processing is necessary for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims or whenever courts are acting in their judicial capacity, processing is necessary for reasons of substantial public interest, processing is necessary for the purposes of preventive or occupational medicine, for the assessment of the working capacity of the employee, medical diagnosis, the provision of health or social care or treatment or the management of health or social care systems and services, processing is necessary for reasons of public interest in the area of public health, such as protecting against serious cross-border threats to health or ensuring high standards of quality and safety of health care and of medicinal products or medical devices, processing is necessary for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes.

context: No, if the purposes for which a controller processes personal data do not or do no longer require the identification of a data subject by the controller, the controller shall not be obliged to maintain, acquire or process additional information in order to identify the data subject for the sole purpose of complying with this Regulation.

text: No, if the purposes for which a controller processes personal data do not or do no longer require the identification of a data subject by the controller, the controller shall not be obliged to maintain, acquire or process additional information in order to identify the data subject for the sole purpose of complying with this Regulation.

context: The controller should take appropriate measures to provide any information referred to in Articles 13 and 14 and any communication under Articles 15 to 22 and 34 relating to processing to the data subject in a concise, transparent, intelligible, and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language, in particular for any information addressed specifically to a child.
question: What measures should the controller take to provide information to the data subject? reference Article 12 Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject
