context: The controller must provide the data subject with the period for which the personal data will be stored, the existence of the right to request access to and rectification or erasure of personal data, the right to object to processing, the right to data portability, the right to withdraw consent, the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority, and the existence of automated decision-making.
question: What additional information must a controller provide to a data subject to ensure fair and transparent processing? reference Article 13 Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller must provide the data subject with the period for which the personal data will be stored, the existence of the right to request access to and rectification or erasure of personal data, the right to object to processing, the right to data portability, the right to withdraw consent, the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority, and the existence of automated decision-making.

context: In addition to the information referred to in paragraph 1, the controller shall provide the data subject with the following information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing in respect of the data subject: the period for which the personal data will be stored, or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; where the processing is based on point (f) of Article 6(1), the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party; the existence of the right to request from the controller access to and rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing concerning the data subject and to object to processing as well as the right to data portability; where processing is based on point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (a) of Article 9(2), the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal; the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority; from which source the personal data originate, and if applicable, whether it came from publicly accessible sources; the existence of automated decision-making, including profiling, referred to in Article 22(1) and (4) and, at least in those cases, meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences of such processing for the data subject.
question: What additional information must a controller provide to a data subject to ensure fair and transparent processing when data have not been obtained from the data subject? reference Article 14 Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: In addition to the information referred to in paragraph 1, the controller shall provide the data subject with the following information necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing in respect of the data subject: the period for which the personal data will be stored, or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; where the processing is based on point (f) of Article 6(1), the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party; the existence of the right to request from the controller access to and rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing concerning the data subject and to object to processing as well as the right to data portability; where processing is based on point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (a) of Article 9(2), the existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal; the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority; from which source the personal data originate, and if applicable, whether it came from publicly accessible sources; the existence of automated decision-making, including profiling, referred to in Article 22(1) and (4) and, at least in those cases, meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences of such processing for the data subject.

context: The controller should provide confirmation as to whether or not personal data concerning the data subject are being processed, and, where that is the case, access to the personal data and information about the purposes of the processing, the categories of personal data concerned, the recipients or categories of recipient to whom the personal data have been or will be disclosed, the envisaged period for which the personal data will be stored, the right to request rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing of personal data, the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority, any available information as to the source of the personal data, the existence of automated decision-making, including profiling, and meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences of such processing for the data subject.
question: What information should the controller provide to the data subject according to Article 15? reference Article 15 Right of access by the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller should provide confirmation as to whether or not personal data concerning the data subject are being processed, and, where that is the case, access to the personal data and information about the purposes of the processing, the categories of personal data concerned, the recipients or categories of recipient to whom the personal data have been or will be disclosed, the envisaged period for which the personal data will be stored, the right to request rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing of personal data, the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority, any available information as to the source of the personal data, the existence of automated decision-making, including profiling, and meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences of such processing for the data subject.

context: The controller must rectify inaccurate personal data without undue delay.
question: What is the time frame for the controller to rectify inaccurate personal data under Article 16 of GDPR? reference Article 16 Right to rectification, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller must rectify inaccurate personal data without undue delay.

context: The controller shall have the obligation to erase personal data without undue delay where one of the grounds listed in Article 17(1) applies.
question: What is the obligation of the controller regarding the right to erasure? reference Article 17 Right to erasure (‘right to be forgotten’), Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller shall have the obligation to erase personal data without undue delay where one of the grounds listed in Article 17(1) applies.

context: A data subject can request restriction of processing if the accuracy of the personal data is contested, if the processing is unlawful and the data subject opposes erasure, if the controller no longer needs the personal data but the data subject requires it for legal claims, or if the data subject has objected to processing pending verification of legitimate grounds.
question: Under what circumstances can a data subject request restriction of processing? reference Article 18 Right to restriction of processing, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: A data subject can request restriction of processing if the accuracy of the personal data is contested, if the processing is unlawful and the data subject opposes erasure, if the controller no longer needs the personal data but the data subject requires it for legal claims, or if the data subject has objected to processing pending verification of legitimate grounds.

context: The controller must communicate any rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing carried out in accordance with Article 16, Article 17(1) and Article 18 to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless this proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort.
question: What actions must the controller communicate to each recipient according to Article 19 of GDPR? reference Article 19 Notification obligation regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller must communicate any rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing carried out in accordance with Article 16, Article 17(1) and Article 18 to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless this proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort.

context: A data subject can exercise the right to data portability where the processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (a) of Article 9(2) or on a contract pursuant to point (b) of Article 6(1), and the processing is carried out by automated means.
question: Under what circumstances can a data subject exercise the right to data portability? reference Article 20 Right to data portability, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: A data subject can exercise the right to data portability where the processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (a) of Article 9(2) or on a contract pursuant to point (b) of Article 6(1), and the processing is carried out by automated means.

context: The controller shall no longer process the personal data unless the controller demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the data subject or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims.
question: What happens if the controller receives an objection from the data subject? reference Article 21 Right to object, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller shall no longer process the personal data unless the controller demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the data subject or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims.

context: According to paragraph 1 of Article 22, the data subject has the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning him or her or similarly significantly affects him or her.
question: What is the right of the data subject according to paragraph 1 of Article 22? reference Article 22 Automated individual decision-making, including profiling, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: According to paragraph 1 of Article 22, the data subject has the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning him or her or similarly significantly affects him or her.

context: Union or Member State law can restrict the scope of obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34, as well as Article 5 when such a restriction respects the essence of the fundamental rights and freedoms and is a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society to safeguard national security, defence, public security, the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, including the safeguarding against and the prevention of threats to public security, other important objectives of general public interest of the Union or of a Member State, in particular an important economic or financial interest of the Union or of a Member State, including monetary, budgetary and taxation a matters, public health and social security, the protection of judicial independence and judicial proceedings, the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of breaches of ethics for regulated professions, a monitoring, inspection or regulatory function connected, even occasionally, to the exercise of official authority in the cases referred to in points (a) to (e) and (g), the protection of the data subject or the rights and freedoms of others, and the enforcement of civil law claims.
question: Under what circumstances can Union or Member State law restrict the scope of obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34, as well as Article 5? reference Article 23 Restrictions, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: Union or Member State law can restrict the scope of obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34, as well as Article 5 when such a restriction respects the essence of the fundamental rights and freedoms and is a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society to safeguard national security, defence, public security, the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, including the safeguarding against and the prevention of threats to public security, other important objectives of general public interest of the Union or of a Member State, in particular an important economic or financial interest of the Union or of a Member State, including monetary, budgetary and taxation a matters, public health and social security, the protection of judicial independence and judicial proceedings, the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of breaches of ethics for regulated professions, a monitoring, inspection or regulatory function connected, even occasionally, to the exercise of official authority in the cases referred to in points (a) to (e) and (g), the protection of the data subject or the rights and freedoms of others, and the enforcement of civil law claims.

context: The controller should take into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing as well as the risks of varying likelihood and severity for the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
question: What factors should the controller take into account when implementing appropriate measures according to Article 24 of GDPR? reference Article 24 Responsibility of the controller, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller should take into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing as well as the risks of varying likelihood and severity for the rights and freedoms of natural persons.

context: The controller should consider the state of the art, the cost of implementation, the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing, and the risks of varying likelihood and severity for rights and freedoms of natural persons posed by the processing when implementing appropriate technical and organizational measures.
question: What factors should the controller consider when implementing appropriate technical and organizational measures? reference Article 25 Data protection by design and by default, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller should consider the state of the art, the cost of implementation, the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing, and the risks of varying likelihood and severity for rights and freedoms of natural persons posed by the processing when implementing appropriate technical and organizational measures.

context: Joint controllers shall in a transparent manner determine their respective responsibilities for compliance with the obligations under this Regulation, in particular as regards the exercising of the rights of the data subject and their respective duties to provide the information referred to in Articles 13 and 14.
question: What is the responsibility of joint controllers under GDPR? reference Article 26 Joint controllers, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Joint controllers shall in a transparent manner determine their respective responsibilities for compliance with the obligations under this Regulation, in particular as regards the exercising of the rights of the data subject and their respective duties to provide the information referred to in Articles 13 and 14.

context: Controllers or processors not established in the Union are required to designate a representative in the Union according to Article 27 of GDPR.
question: Who is required to designate a representative in the Union according to Article 27 of GDPR? reference Article 27 Representatives of controllers or processors not established in the Union, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Controllers or processors not established in the Union are required to designate a representative in the Union according to Article 27 of GDPR.

context: Under a contract or legal act with a controller, a processor must process personal data only on documented instructions from the controller, ensure confidentiality of authorized personnel, take measures required by Article 32, respect conditions for engaging another processor, assist the controller in responding to data subject requests, assist the controller in ensuring compliance with GDPR, delete or return personal data to the controller after the end of processing, and make available all information necessary to demonstrate compliance and allow for audits.
question: What are the obligations of a processor under a contract or legal act with a controller? reference Article 28 Processor, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Under a contract or legal act with a controller, a processor must process personal data only on documented instructions from the controller, ensure confidentiality of authorized personnel, take measures required by Article 32, respect conditions for engaging another processor, assist the controller in responding to data subject requests, assist the controller in ensuring compliance with GDPR, delete or return personal data to the controller after the end of processing, and make available all information necessary to demonstrate compliance and allow for audits.

context: The controller provides instructions to the processor and any person acting under their authority on how to process personal data.
question: What is the role of the controller in processing personal data? reference Article 29 Processing under the authority of the controller or processor, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller provides instructions to the processor and any person acting under their authority on how to process personal data.

context: Each controller and, where applicable, the controller's representative, is responsible for maintaining a record of processing activities under its responsibility.
question: Who is responsible for maintaining a record of processing activities? reference Article 30 Records of processing activities, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Each controller and, where applicable, the controller's representative, is responsible for maintaining a record of processing activities under its responsibility.

context: To assist the supervisory authority in the performance of its tasks.
question: What is the purpose of cooperation with the supervisory authority? reference Article 31 Cooperation with the supervisory authority, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: To assist the supervisory authority in the performance of its tasks.

context: The technical and organizational measures that the controller and processor should implement according to Article 32 include pseudonymisation and encryption of personal data, ensuring the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems and services, restoring the availability and access to personal data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incident, and regularly testing, assessing, and evaluating the effectiveness of technical and organizational measures for ensuring the security of the processing.
question: What are the technical and organizational measures that the controller and processor should implement according to Article 32? reference Article 32 Security of processing, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The technical and organizational measures that the controller and processor should implement according to Article 32 include pseudonymisation and encryption of personal data, ensuring the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability, and resilience of processing systems and services, restoring the availability and access to personal data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incident, and regularly testing, assessing, and evaluating the effectiveness of technical and organizational measures for ensuring the security of the processing.

context: The processor shall notify the controller without undue delay after becoming aware of a personal data breach.
question: Who should the processor notify in case of a personal data breach? reference Article 33 Notification of a personal data breach to the supervisory authority, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The processor shall notify the controller without undue delay after becoming aware of a personal data breach.

context: The communication to the data subject shall describe in clear and plain language the nature of the personal data breach and contain at least the information and measures referred to in points (b), (c) and (d) of Article 33(3).
question: What information must be included in the communication to the data subject? reference Article 34 Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The communication to the data subject shall describe in clear and plain language the nature of the personal data breach and contain at least the information and measures referred to in points (b), (c) and (d) of Article 33(3).

context: The controller shall seek the advice of the data protection officer, where designated, when carrying out a data protection impact assessment.
question: What is the purpose of seeking advice from the data protection officer? reference Article 35 Data protection impact assessment, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller shall seek the advice of the data protection officer, where designated, when carrying out a data protection impact assessment.

context: The supervisory authority shall provide written advice to the controller and, where applicable to the processor, and may use any of its powers referred to in Article 58. That period may be extended by six weeks, taking into account the complexity of the intended processing.
question: What happens if the supervisory authority believes that the intended processing would infringe the GDPR? reference Article 36 Prior consultation, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The supervisory authority shall provide written advice to the controller and, where applicable to the processor, and may use any of its powers referred to in Article 58. That period may be extended by six weeks, taking into account the complexity of the intended processing.

context: Yes, a group of undertakings may appoint a single data protection officer provided that a data protection officer is easily accessible from each establishment.
question: Can a group of undertakings appoint a single data protection officer? reference Article 37 Designation of the data protection officer, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Yes, a group of undertakings may appoint a single data protection officer provided that a data protection officer is easily accessible from each establishment.

context: The data protection officer is responsible for monitoring compliance with GDPR, with other Union or Member State data protection provisions and with the policies of the controller or processor in relation to the protection of personal data, including the assignment of responsibilities, awareness-raising and training of staff involved in processing operations, and the related audits.
question: What is the role of the data protection officer in relation to compliance monitoring? reference Article 39 Tasks of the data protection officer, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The data protection officer is responsible for monitoring compliance with GDPR, with other Union or Member State data protection provisions and with the policies of the controller or processor in relation to the protection of personal data, including the assignment of responsibilities, awareness-raising and training of staff involved in processing operations, and the related audits.

context: The controller and processor should provide resources necessary to carry out the tasks referred to in Article 39, access to personal data and processing operations, and maintain the data protection officer's expert knowledge.
question: What resources should the controller and processor provide to the data protection officer? reference Article 38 Position of the data protection officer, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller and processor should provide resources necessary to carry out the tasks referred to in Article 39, access to personal data and processing operations, and maintain the data protection officer's expert knowledge.

context: Associations and other bodies representing categories of controllers or processors may prepare codes of conduct, or amend or extend such codes, for the purpose of specifying the application of GDPR.
question: Who can prepare codes of conduct according to GDPR? reference Article 40 Codes of conduct, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Associations and other bodies representing categories of controllers or processors may prepare codes of conduct, or amend or extend such codes, for the purpose of specifying the application of GDPR.

context: A body which has an appropriate level of expertise in relation to the subject-matter of the code and is accredited for that purpose by the competent supervisory authority can carry out the monitoring of compliance with a code of conduct.
question: Who can carry out the monitoring of compliance with a code of conduct? reference Article 41 Monitoring of approved codes of conduct, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: A body which has an appropriate level of expertise in relation to the subject-matter of the code and is accredited for that purpose by the competent supervisory authority can carry out the monitoring of compliance with a code of conduct.

context: The Member States, the supervisory authorities, the Board and the Commission should take into account the specific needs of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises when encouraging the establishment of data protection certification mechanisms.
question: Who should take into account the specific needs of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises when encouraging the establishment of data protection certification mechanisms? reference Article 42 Certification, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The Member States, the supervisory authorities, the Board and the Commission should take into account the specific needs of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises when encouraging the establishment of data protection certification mechanisms.

context: Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures based on Article 6(1) shall be carried out only under the control of official authority or when the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.
question: Who is authorized to carry out the processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences? reference Article 10 Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures based on Article 6(1) shall be carried out only under the control of official authority or when the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects.

context: The purpose of Chapter 5 of the GDPR is to ensure that the level of protection of natural persons guaranteed by the regulation is not undermined when personal data is transferred to a third country or international organization.
question: What is the purpose of Chapter 5 of the GDPR? reference Article 44 General principle for transfers, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: The purpose of Chapter 5 of the GDPR is to ensure that the level of protection of natural persons guaranteed by the regulation is not undermined when personal data is transferred to a third country or international organization.

context: Certification bodies must demonstrate their independence and expertise in relation to the subject-matter of the certification to the satisfaction of the competent supervisory authority.
question: What must certification bodies demonstrate to be accredited under GDPR? reference Article 43 Certification bodies, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Certification bodies must demonstrate their independence and expertise in relation to the subject-matter of the certification to the satisfaction of the competent supervisory authority.

context: When assessing the adequacy of the level of protection, the Commission takes into account the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, relevant legislation, both general and sectoral, including concerning public security, defence, national security and criminal law and the access of public authorities to personal data, as well as the implementation of such legislation, data protection rules, professional rules and security measures, including rules for the onward transfer of personal data to another third country or international organization which are complied with in that country or international organization, case-law, as well as effective and enforceable data subject rights and effective administrative and judicial redress for the data subjects whose personal data are being transferred.
question: What factors does the Commission take into account when assessing the adequacy of the level of protection? reference Article 45 Transfers on the basis of an adequacy decision, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: When assessing the adequacy of the level of protection, the Commission takes into account the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, relevant legislation, both general and sectoral, including concerning public security, defence, national security and criminal law and the access of public authorities to personal data, as well as the implementation of such legislation, data protection rules, professional rules and security measures, including rules for the onward transfer of personal data to another third country or international organization which are complied with in that country or international organization, case-law, as well as effective and enforceable data subject rights and effective administrative and judicial redress for the data subjects whose personal data are being transferred.

context: The appropriate safeguards that a controller or processor can provide for transferring personal data to a third country or international organization are: a) a legally binding and enforceable instrument between public authorities or bodies; b) binding corporate rules in accordance with Article 47; c) standard data protection clauses adopted by the Commission in accordance with the examination procedure referred to in Article 93(2); d) standard data protection clauses adopted by a supervisory authority and approved by the Commission pursuant to the examination procedure referred to in Article 93(2); e) an approved code of conduct pursuant to Article 40 together with binding and enforceable commitments of the controller or processor in the third country to apply the appropriate safeguards, including as regards data subjects' rights; or f) an approved certification mechanism pursuant to Article 42 together with binding and enforceable commitments of the controller or processor in the third country to apply the appropriate safeguards, including as regards data subjects' rights.
question: What are the appropriate safeguards that a controller or processor can provide for transferring personal data to a third country or international organization? reference Article 46 Transfers subject to appropriate safeguards, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: The appropriate safeguards that a controller or processor can provide for transferring personal data to a third country or international organization are: a) a legally binding and enforceable instrument between public authorities or bodies; b) binding corporate rules in accordance with Article 47; c) standard data protection clauses adopted by the Commission in accordance with the examination procedure referred to in Article 93(2); d) standard data protection clauses adopted by a supervisory authority and approved by the Commission pursuant to the examination procedure referred to in Article 93(2); e) an approved code of conduct pursuant to Article 40 together with binding and enforceable commitments of the controller or processor in the third country to apply the appropriate safeguards, including as regards data subjects' rights; or f) an approved certification mechanism pursuant to Article 42 together with binding and enforceable commitments of the controller or processor in the third country to apply the appropriate safeguards, including as regards data subjects' rights.

context: A judgment of a court or tribunal or decision of an administrative authority of a third country can only be recognized or enforceable in any manner if it is based on an international agreement, such as a mutual legal assistance treaty, in force between the requesting third country and the Union or a Member State.
question: What is the condition for a judgment of a court or tribunal or decision of an administrative authority of a third country to be recognized or enforceable in any manner? reference Article 48 Transfers or disclosures not authorised by Union law, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: A judgment of a court or tribunal or decision of an administrative authority of a third country can only be recognized or enforceable in any manner if it is based on an international agreement, such as a mutual legal assistance treaty, in force between the requesting third country and the Union or a Member State.

context: Binding corporate rules must be legally binding and enforced by every member of the group of undertakings, confer enforceable rights on data subjects, and fulfill the requirements laid down in paragraph 2 of Article 47.
question: What are the three requirements that binding corporate rules must fulfill to be approved by the competent supervisory authority? reference Article 47 Binding corporate rules, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: Binding corporate rules must be legally binding and enforced by every member of the group of undertakings, confer enforceable rights on data subjects, and fulfill the requirements laid down in paragraph 2 of Article 47.

context: If a transfer to a third country or international organization could not be based on a provision in Article 45 or 46 and none of the derogations for a specific situation is applicable, the transfer may take place only if the transfer is not repetitive, concerns only a limited number of data subjects, is necessary for the purposes of compelling legitimate interests pursued by the controller which are not overridden by the interests or rights and freedoms of the data subject, and the controller has assessed all the circumstances surrounding the data transfer and has on the basis of that assessment provided suitable safeguards with regard to the protection of personal data. The controller shall inform the supervisory authority of the transfer. The controller shall, in addition to providing the information referred to in Articles 13 and 14, inform the data subject of the transfer and on the compelling legitimate interests pursued.
question: What must the controller do if a transfer to a third country or international organization could not be based on a provision in Article 45 or 46 and none of the derogations for a specific situation is applicable? reference Article 49 Derogations for specific situations, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: If a transfer to a third country or international organization could not be based on a provision in Article 45 or 46 and none of the derogations for a specific situation is applicable, the transfer may take place only if the transfer is not repetitive, concerns only a limited number of data subjects, is necessary for the purposes of compelling legitimate interests pursued by the controller which are not overridden by the interests or rights and freedoms of the data subject, and the controller has assessed all the circumstances surrounding the data transfer and has on the basis of that assessment provided suitable safeguards with regard to the protection of personal data. The controller shall inform the supervisory authority of the transfer. The controller shall, in addition to providing the information referred to in Articles 13 and 14, inform the data subject of the transfer and on the compelling legitimate interests pursued.

context: The Commission and supervisory authorities are responsible for taking appropriate steps to develop international cooperation mechanisms for the protection of personal data.
question: Who is responsible for taking appropriate steps to develop international cooperation mechanisms for the protection of personal data? reference Article 50 International cooperation for the protection of personal data, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: The Commission and supervisory authorities are responsible for taking appropriate steps to develop international cooperation mechanisms for the protection of personal data.

context: Each Member State should provide for one or more independent public authorities.
question: How many independent public authorities should each Member State provide for? reference Article 51 Supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Each Member State should provide for one or more independent public authorities.

context: The member or members of each supervisory authority shall, in the performance of their tasks and exercise of their powers in accordance with this Regulation, remain free from external influence, whether direct or indirect, and shall neither seek nor take instructions from anybody.
question: What is the requirement for the member or members of each supervisory authority in the performance of their tasks and exercise of their powers? reference Article 52 Independence, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: The member or members of each supervisory authority shall, in the performance of their tasks and exercise of their powers in accordance with this Regulation, remain free from external influence, whether direct or indirect, and shall neither seek nor take instructions from anybody.

context: Each member of the supervisory authority shall have the qualifications, experience and skills, in particular in the area of the protection of personal data, required to perform its duties and exercise its powers.
question: What qualifications are required for each member of the supervisory authority? reference Article 53 General conditions for the members of the supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Each member of the supervisory authority shall have the qualifications, experience and skills, in particular in the area of the protection of personal data, required to perform its duties and exercise its powers.

context: Each Member State must provide by law for the establishment of each supervisory authority, the qualifications and eligibility conditions required to be appointed as a member of each supervisory authority, the rules and procedures for the appointment of the member or members of each supervisory authority, the duration of the term of the member or members of each supervisory authority, whether and, if so, for how many terms the member or members of each supervisory authority are eligible for reappointment, and the conditions governing the obligations of the member or members and staff of each supervisory authority, prohibitions on actions, occupations and benefits incompatible therewith during and after the term of office, and rules governing the cessation of employment.
question: What are the requirements that each Member State must provide by law according to Article 54? reference Article 54 Rules on the establishment of the supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Each Member State must provide by law for the establishment of each supervisory authority, the qualifications and eligibility conditions required to be appointed as a member of each supervisory authority, the rules and procedures for the appointment of the member or members of each supervisory authority, the duration of the term of the member or members of each supervisory authority, whether and, if so, for how many terms the member or members of each supervisory authority are eligible for reappointment, and the conditions governing the obligations of the member or members and staff of each supervisory authority, prohibitions on actions, occupations and benefits incompatible therewith during and after the term of office, and rules governing the cessation of employment.

context: The supervisory authority of the Member State concerned shall be competent.
question: Which supervisory authority is competent when processing is carried out by public authorities or private bodies based on Article 6(1)(c) or (e)? reference Article 55 Competence, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: The supervisory authority of the Member State concerned shall be competent.

context: If the subject matter relates only to an establishment in its Member State or substantially affects data subjects only in its Member State.
question: Under what circumstances can each supervisory authority handle a complaint or possible infringement of GDPR? reference Article 56 Competence of the lead supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: If the subject matter relates only to an establishment in its Member State or substantially affects data subjects only in its Member State.

context: The purpose of supervisory authorities promoting public awareness and understanding of the risks, rules, safeguards, and rights in relation to processing is to ensure that data subjects are informed about their rights and how their personal data is being processed.
question: What is the purpose of supervisory authorities promoting public awareness and understanding of the risks, rules, safeguards, and rights in relation to processing? reference Article 57 Tasks, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: The purpose of supervisory authorities promoting public awareness and understanding of the risks, rules, safeguards, and rights in relation to processing is to ensure that data subjects are informed about their rights and how their personal data is being processed.

context: Each supervisory authority shall have the power to issue warnings to a controller or processor that intended processing operations are likely to infringe provisions of this Regulation, issue reprimands to a controller or a processor where processing operations have infringed provisions of this Regulation, order the controller or the processor to comply with the data subject's requests to exercise his or her rights pursuant to this Regulation, order the controller or processor to bring processing operations into compliance with the provisions of this Regulation, where appropriate, in a specified manner and within a specified period, order the controller to communicate a personal data breach to the data subject, impose a temporary or definitive limitation including a ban on processing, order the rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing pursuant to Articles 16, 17, and 18 and the notification of such actions to recipients to whom the personal data have been disclosed pursuant to Article 17(2) and Article 19, withdraw a certification or to order the certification body to withdraw a certification issued pursuant to Articles 42 and 43, or to order the certification body not to issue certification if the requirements for the certification are not or are no longer met, impose an administrative fine pursuant to Article 83, in addition to, or instead of measures referred to in this paragraph, depending on the circumstances of each individual case, order the suspension of data flows to a recipient in a third country or to an international organization.
question: What are the corrective powers of each supervisory authority according to GDPR? reference Article 58 Powers, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Each supervisory authority shall have the power to issue warnings to a controller or processor that intended processing operations are likely to infringe provisions of this Regulation, issue reprimands to a controller or a processor where processing operations have infringed provisions of this Regulation, order the controller or the processor to comply with the data subject's requests to exercise his or her rights pursuant to this Regulation, order the controller or processor to bring processing operations into compliance with the provisions of this Regulation, where appropriate, in a specified manner and within a specified period, order the controller to communicate a personal data breach to the data subject, impose a temporary or definitive limitation including a ban on processing, order the rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing pursuant to Articles 16, 17, and 18 and the notification of such actions to recipients to whom the personal data have been disclosed pursuant to Article 17(2) and Article 19, withdraw a certification or to order the certification body to withdraw a certification issued pursuant to Articles 42 and 43, or to order the certification body not to issue certification if the requirements for the certification are not or are no longer met, impose an administrative fine pursuant to Article 83, in addition to, or instead of measures referred to in this paragraph, depending on the circumstances of each individual case, order the suspension of data flows to a recipient in a third country or to an international organization.

context: The annual report required by Article 59 may include a list of types of infringement notified and types of measures taken in accordance with Article 58(2).

text: The annual report required by Article 59 may include a list of types of infringement notified and types of measures taken in accordance with Article 58(2).

context: The lead supervisory authority shall cooperate with the other supervisory authorities concerned in an endeavour to reach consensus. The lead supervisory authority and the supervisory authorities concerned shall exchange all relevant information with each other.

text: The lead supervisory authority shall cooperate with the other supervisory authorities concerned in an endeavour to reach consensus. The lead supervisory authority and the supervisory authorities concerned shall exchange all relevant information with each other.

context: Mutual assistance according to GDPR covers information requests and supervisory measures, such as requests to carry out prior authorisations and consultations, inspections and investigations.
question: What does mutual assistance cover according to GDPR? reference Article 61 Mutual assistance, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: Mutual assistance according to GDPR covers information requests and supervisory measures, such as requests to carry out prior authorisations and consultations, inspections and investigations.

context: The supervisory authorities are responsible for cooperating with each other and, where relevant, with the Commission, through the consistency mechanism as set out in this Section.

text: The supervisory authorities are responsible for cooperating with each other and, where relevant, with the Commission, through the consistency mechanism as set out in this Section.

context: Supervisory authorities can conduct joint operations where appropriate, including joint investigations and joint enforcement measures in which members or staff of the supervisory authorities of other Member States are involved.

text: Supervisory authorities can conduct joint operations where appropriate, including joint investigations and joint enforcement measures in which members or staff of the supervisory authorities of other Member States are involved.

context: The measures that require the Board to issue an opinion are: (a) adopting a list of processing operations subject to the requirement for a data protection impact assessment, (b) determining whether a draft code of conduct complies with GDPR, (c) approving the criteria for accreditation of a body or a certification body, (d) determining standard data protection clauses, (e) authorizing contractual clauses, and (f) approving binding corporate rules.
question: What are the measures that require the Board to issue an opinion? reference Article 64 Opinion of the Board, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The measures that require the Board to issue an opinion are: (a) adopting a list of processing operations subject to the requirement for a data protection impact assessment, (b) determining whether a draft code of conduct complies with GDPR, (c) approving the criteria for accreditation of a body or a certification body, (d) determining standard data protection clauses, (e) authorizing contractual clauses, and (f) approving binding corporate rules.

context: The maximum validity period for provisional measures adopted by a supervisory authority is three months.
question: What is the maximum validity period for provisional measures adopted by a supervisory authority? reference Article 66 Urgency procedure, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The maximum validity period for provisional measures adopted by a supervisory authority is three months.

context: The Commission can adopt implementing acts of general scope to specify the arrangements for the exchange of information by electronic means.
question: Who can adopt implementing acts of general scope to specify the arrangements for the exchange of information by electronic means? reference Article 67 Exchange of information, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The Commission can adopt implementing acts of general scope to specify the arrangements for the exchange of information by electronic means.

context: The Board shall adopt a binding decision in the following cases: (a) where, in a case referred to in Article 60(4), a supervisory authority concerned has raised a relevant and reasoned objection to a draft decision of the lead authority or the lead authority has rejected such an objection as being not relevant or reasoned; (b) where there are conflicting views on which of the supervisory authorities concerned is competent for the main establishment; (c) where a competent supervisory authority does not request the opinion of the Board in the cases referred to in Article 64(1), or does not follow the opinion of the Board issued under Article 64.
question: What are the cases in which the Board shall adopt a binding decision? reference Article 65 Dispute resolution by the Board, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The Board shall adopt a binding decision in the following cases: (a) where, in a case referred to in Article 60(4), a supervisory authority concerned has raised a relevant and reasoned objection to a draft decision of the lead authority or the lead authority has rejected such an objection as being not relevant or reasoned; (b) where there are conflicting views on which of the supervisory authorities concerned is competent for the main establishment; (c) where a competent supervisory authority does not request the opinion of the Board in the cases referred to in Article 64(1), or does not follow the opinion of the Board issued under Article 64.

context: The European Data Protection Board is represented by its Chair.

text: The European Data Protection Board is represented by its Chair.

text: The Board is required to act independently when performing its tasks or exercising its powers pursuant to Articles 70 and 71, according to Article 69 of GDPR.

context: The Board issues guidelines, recommendations, and best practices for establishing personal data breaches and determining the undue delay referred to in Article 33(1) and (2) and for the particular circumstances in which a controller or a processor is required to notify the personal data breach. It also issues guidelines, recommendations, and best practices as to the circumstances in which a personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of the natural persons referred to in Article 34(1).
question: What tasks does the Board have in relation to personal data breaches? reference Article 70 Tasks of the Board, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The Board issues guidelines, recommendations, and best practices for establishing personal data breaches and determining the undue delay referred to in Article 33(1) and (2) and for the particular circumstances in which a controller or a processor is required to notify the personal data breach. It also issues guidelines, recommendations, and best practices as to the circumstances in which a personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of the natural persons referred to in Article 34(1).

context: The Board is responsible for drawing up the annual report mentioned in Article 71 of GDPR.

context: The Board elects two deputy chairs from amongst its members by simple majority.
question: How many deputy chairs are elected by the Board? reference Article 73 Chair, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The Board elects two deputy chairs from amongst its members by simple majority.

context: The consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63 of GDPR is a mechanism for ensuring the consistent application of GDPR by supervisory authorities.
question: What is the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63 of GDPR used for in Article 74? reference Article 74 Tasks of the Chair, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63 of GDPR is a mechanism for ensuring the consistent application of GDPR by supervisory authorities.

context: The Secretariat is provided by the European Data Protection Supervisor.

text: The Secretariat is provided by the European Data Protection Supervisor.

context: Where the Board deems it necessary, as provided for in its rules of procedure.

text: Where the Board deems it necessary, as provided for in its rules of procedure.

context: Every data subject has the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority.
question: Who has the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority according to Article 77 of GDPR? reference Article 77 Right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: Every data subject has the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority.

context: Each natural or legal person and each data subject have the right to an effective judicial remedy according to Article 78 of GDPR.
question: Who has the right to an effective judicial remedy according to Article 78 of GDPR? reference Article 78 Right to an effective judicial remedy against a supervisory authority, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: Each natural or legal person and each data subject have the right to an effective judicial remedy according to Article 78 of GDPR.

context: A data subject has the right to an effective judicial remedy where he or she considers that his or her rights under this Regulation have been infringed as a result of the processing of his or her personal data in non-compliance with this Regulation. Additionally, the data subject has the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority pursuant to Article 77.
question: What are the available remedies for a data subject whose rights have been infringed under GDPR? reference Article 79 Right to an effective judicial remedy against a controller or processor, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: A data subject has the right to an effective judicial remedy where he or she considers that his or her rights under this Regulation have been infringed as a result of the processing of his or her personal data in non-compliance with this Regulation. Additionally, the data subject has the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority pursuant to Article 77.

context: The not-for-profit body, organisation or association must be properly constituted in accordance with the law of a Member State, have statutory objectives which are in the public interest, and be active in the field of the protection of data subjects' rights and freedoms with regard to the protection of their personal data.
question: What are the requirements for the not-for-profit body, organisation or association to be mandated by the data subject? reference Article 80 Representation of data subjects, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: The not-for-profit body, organisation or association must be properly constituted in accordance with the law of a Member State, have statutory objectives which are in the public interest, and be active in the field of the protection of data subjects' rights and freedoms with regard to the protection of their personal data.

context: If a competent court of a Member State has information on proceedings concerning the same subject matter as regards processing by the same controller or processor that are pending in a court in another Member State, it shall contact that court in the other Member State to confirm the existence of such proceedings.
question: What should a competent court of a Member State do if it has information on proceedings concerning the same subject matter as regards processing by the same controller or processor that are pending in a court in another Member State? reference Article 81 Suspension of proceedings, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: If a competent court of a Member State has information on proceedings concerning the same subject matter as regards processing by the same controller or processor that are pending in a court in another Member State, it shall contact that court in the other Member State to confirm the existence of such proceedings.

context: Any controller involved in processing shall be liable for the damage caused by processing which infringes this Regulation. A processor shall be liable for the damage caused by processing only where it has not complied with obligations of this Regulation specifically directed to processors or where it has acted outside or contrary to lawful instructions of the controller.
question: Who is liable for the damage caused by processing which infringes GDPR? reference Article 82 Right to compensation and liability, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: Any controller involved in processing shall be liable for the damage caused by processing which infringes this Regulation. A processor shall be liable for the damage caused by processing only where it has not complied with obligations of this Regulation specifically directed to processors or where it has acted outside or contrary to lawful instructions of the controller.

context: Infringements of the obligations of the controller and the processor pursuant to Articles 8, 11, 25 to 39 and 42 and 43 shall be subject to administrative fines up to 10 000 000 EUR, or in the case of an undertaking, up to 2 % of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher.
question: What is the maximum amount of administrative fine for infringements of obligations of the controller and the processor pursuant to Articles 8, 11, 25 to 39 and 42 and 43? reference Article 83 General conditions for imposing administrative fines, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: Infringements of the obligations of the controller and the processor pursuant to Articles 8, 11, 25 to 39 and 42 and 43 shall be subject to administrative fines up to 10 000 000 EUR, or in the case of an undertaking, up to 2 % of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher.

question: What kind of penalties should be implemented by Member States according to Article 84? reference Article 84 Penalties, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: Member States should implement penalties that are effective, proportionate and dissuasive according to Article 84.

context: For processing carried out for journalistic purposes or the purpose of academic artistic or literary expression, Member States shall provide for exemptions or derogations from Chapter II (principles), Chapter III (rights of the data subject), Chapter IV (controller and processor), Chapter V (transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations), Chapter VI (independent supervisory authorities), Chapter VII (cooperation and consistency) and Chapter IX (specific data processing situations) if they are necessary to reconcile the right to the protection of personal data with the freedom of expression and information.
question: What exemptions or derogations are provided by Member States for processing carried out for journalistic purposes or the purpose of academic artistic or literary expression? reference Article 85 Processing and freedom of expression and information, Chapter 9 Provisions relating to specific processing situations

text: For processing carried out for journalistic purposes or the purpose of academic artistic or literary expression, Member States shall provide for exemptions or derogations from Chapter II (principles), Chapter III (rights of the data subject), Chapter IV (controller and processor), Chapter V (transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations), Chapter VI (independent supervisory authorities), Chapter VII (cooperation and consistency) and Chapter IX (specific data processing situations) if they are necessary to reconcile the right to the protection of personal data with the freedom of expression and information.

context: The rules provided by Member States or collective agreements can pertain to various aspects of employment, including recruitment, performance of the employment contract, management, planning and organization of work, equality and diversity in the workplace, health and safety at work, protection of employer's or customer's property, and the exercise and enjoyment of rights and benefits related to employment, as well as the termination of the employment relationship.
question: What aspects of employment can the rules provided by Member States or collective agreements pertain to? reference Article 88 Processing in the context of employment, Chapter 9 Provisions relating to specific processing situations

text: The rules provided by Member States or collective agreements can pertain to various aspects of employment, including recruitment, performance of the employment contract, management, planning and organization of work, equality and diversity in the workplace, health and safety at work, protection of employer's or customer's property, and the exercise and enjoyment of rights and benefits related to employment, as well as the termination of the employment relationship.

context: Yes, provided that they are brought into line with the GDPR.

context: No, GDPR shall not impose additional obligations on natural or legal persons in relation to processing in connection with the provision of publicly available electronic communications services in public communication networks in the Union in relation to matters for which they are subject to specific obligations with the same objective set out in Directive 2002/58/EC.

text: The Commission shall submit a report on the evaluation and review of this Regulation to the European Parliament and to the Council by 25 May 2020 and every four years thereafter.

context: The free movement of personal data within the Union refers to the unrestricted and unprohibited movement of personal data for reasons connected with the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.

text: The free movement of personal data within the Union refers to the unrestricted and unprohibited movement of personal data for reasons connected with the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.

context: For the processing of personal data by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applies. question: What applies to the processing of personal data by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies? reference Article 2 Material scope, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: For the processing of personal data by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applies. Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 and other Union legal acts applicable to such processing of personal data shall be adapted to the principles and rules of this Regulation in accordance with Article 98.

context: GDPR applies to the processing of personal data of data subjects who are not in the Union if the processing activities are related to the offering of goods or services to such data subjects in the Union or the monitoring of their behavior as far as their behavior takes place within the Union.
question: Under what circumstances does GDPR apply to the processing of personal data of data subjects who are not in the Union? reference Article 3 Territorial scope, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: GDPR applies to the processing of personal data of data subjects who are not in the Union if the processing activities are related to the offering of goods or services to such data subjects in the Union or the monitoring of their behavior as far as their behavior takes place within the Union.

context: Profiling means any form of automated processing of personal data consisting of the use of personal data to evaluate certain personal aspects relating to a natural person, in particular to analyse or predict aspects concerning that natural person's performance at work, economic situation, health, personal preferences, interests, reliability, behaviour, location or movements.
question: What is the definition of profiling according to GDPR? reference Article 4 Definitions, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: Profiling means any form of automated processing of personal data consisting of the use of personal data to evaluate certain personal aspects relating to a natural person, in particular to analyse or predict aspects concerning that natural person's performance at work, economic situation, health, personal preferences, interests, reliability, behaviour, location or movements.

context: 'Supervisory authority' means an independent public authority which is established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51.
question: What is the definition of 'supervisory authority' according to GDPR? reference Article 4 Definitions, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: 'Supervisory authority' means an independent public authority which is established by a Member State pursuant to Article 51.

context: The principle of data minimisation states that personal data should be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed.
question: What does the principle of data minimisation state? reference Article 5 Principles relating to processing of personal data, Chapter 2 Principles

text: The principle of data minimisation states that personal data should be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed.

context: No, point (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6 does not apply to processing carried out by public authorities in the performance of their tasks.

text: No, point (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6 does not apply to processing carried out by public authorities in the performance of their tasks.

context: Yes, the data subject shall have the right to withdraw his or her consent at any time. The withdrawal of consent shall not affect the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal.
question: Can a data subject withdraw their consent for processing their personal data? reference Article 7 Conditions for consent, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Yes, the data subject shall have the right to withdraw his or her consent at any time. The withdrawal of consent shall not affect the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal.

context: Member States may provide by law for a lower age for those purposes provided that such lower age is not below 13 years.
question: What is the exception to the age limit for processing personal data of a child in relation to information society services? reference Article 8 Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Member States may provide by law for a lower age for those purposes provided that such lower age is not below 13 years.

context: Personal data concerning health may be processed for the purposes of preventive or occupational medicine, for the assessment of the working capacity of the employee, medical diagnosis, the provision of health or social care or treatment or the management of health or social care systems and services on the basis of Union or Member State law or pursuant to contract with a health professional and subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in paragraph 3.
question: What is the exception to the prohibition of processing personal data concerning health? reference Article 9 Processing of special categories of personal data, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Personal data concerning health may be processed for the purposes of preventive or occupational medicine, for the assessment of the working capacity of the employee, medical diagnosis, the provision of health or social care or treatment or the management of health or social care systems and services on the basis of Union or Member State law or pursuant to contract with a health professional and subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in paragraph 3.

context: If the controller is not able to identify the data subject, the controller shall inform the data subject accordingly, if possible.
question: What happens if the controller is not able to identify the data subject? reference Article 11 Processing which does not require identification, Chapter 2 Principles

text: If the controller is not able to identify the data subject, the controller shall inform the data subject accordingly, if possible.

context: When requested by the data subject, the information may be provided orally, provided that the identity of the data subject is proven by other means.
question: What should the controller do if the data subject requests information orally? reference Article 12 Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: When requested by the data subject, the information may be provided orally, provided that the identity of the data subject is proven by other means.

context: The controller must provide the data subject with information on further processing of personal data prior to that further processing.
question: When must a controller provide a data subject with information on further processing of personal data? reference Article 13 Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller must provide the data subject with information on further processing of personal data prior to that further processing.

context: The controller shall provide the information referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 within a reasonable period after obtaining the personal data, but at the latest within one month, having regard to the specific circumstances in which the personal data are processed; if the personal data are to be used for communication with the data subject, at the latest at the time of the first communication to that data subject; or if a disclosure to another recipient is envisaged, at the latest when the personal data are first disclosed.
question: When must a controller provide the information referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 to a data subject? reference Article 14 Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller shall provide the information referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 within a reasonable period after obtaining the personal data, but at the latest within one month, having regard to the specific circumstances in which the personal data are processed; if the personal data are to be used for communication with the data subject, at the latest at the time of the first communication to that data subject; or if a disclosure to another recipient is envisaged, at the latest when the personal data are first disclosed.

context: If personal data are transferred to a third country or to an international organization, the data subject has the right to be informed of the appropriate safeguards pursuant to Article 46 relating to the transfer.
question: What is the data subject's right if personal data are transferred to a third country or to an international organization? reference Article 15 Right of access by the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: If personal data are transferred to a third country or to an international organization, the data subject has the right to be informed of the appropriate safeguards pursuant to Article 46 relating to the transfer.

context: The data subject shall have the right to have incomplete personal data completed, including by means of providing a supplementary statement.
question: What is the right of the data subject with regards to incomplete personal data under Article 16 of GDPR? reference Article 16 Right to rectification, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The data subject shall have the right to have incomplete personal data completed, including by means of providing a supplementary statement.

context: The grounds for the right to erasure are: (a) the personal data are no longer necessary in relation to the purposes for which they were collected or otherwise processed; (b) (c) (d) (e) (f) the data subject withdraws consent on which the processing is based according to point (a) of Article 6(1), or point (a) of Article 9(2), and where there is no other legal ground for the processing; the data subject objects to the processing pursuant to Article 21(1) and there are no overriding legitimate grounds for the processing, or the data subject objects to the processing pursuant to Article 21(2); the personal data have been unlawfully processed; the personal data have to be erased for compliance with a legal obligation in Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject; the personal data have been collected in relation to the offer of information society services referred to in Article 8(1).
question: What are the grounds for the right to erasure? reference Article 17 Right to erasure (‘right to be forgotten’), Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The grounds for the right to erasure are: (a) the personal data are no longer necessary in relation to the purposes for which they were collected or otherwise processed; (b) (c) (d) (e) (f) the data subject withdraws consent on which the processing is based according to point (a) of Article 6(1), or point (a) of Article 9(2), and where there is no other legal ground for the processing; the data subject objects to the processing pursuant to Article 21(1) and there are no overriding legitimate grounds for the processing, or the data subject objects to the processing pursuant to Article 21(2); the personal data have been unlawfully processed; the personal data have to be erased for compliance with a legal obligation in Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject; the personal data have been collected in relation to the offer of information society services referred to in Article 8(1).

context: Personal data that has been restricted under Article 18 of GDPR shall only be processed with the data subject's consent or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims or for the protection of the rights of another natural or legal person or for reasons of important public interest of the Union or of a Member State, with the exception of storage.
question: What happens to personal data that has been restricted under Article 18 of GDPR? reference Article 18 Right to restriction of processing, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: Personal data that has been restricted under Article 18 of GDPR shall only be processed with the data subject's consent or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims or for the protection of the rights of another natural or legal person or for reasons of important public interest of the Union or of a Member State, with the exception of storage.

context: The controller is responsible for informing the data subject about the recipients of their personal data if the data subject requests it.

text: The controller is responsible for informing the data subject about the recipients of their personal data if the data subject requests it.

context: When exercising the right to data portability, the data subject shall have the right to have the personal data transmitted directly from one controller to another, where technically feasible.

text: When exercising the right to data portability, the data subject shall have the right to have the personal data transmitted directly from one controller to another, where technically feasible.

context: The data subject shall have the right to object at any time to processing of personal data concerning him or her for such marketing, which includes profiling to the extent that it is related to such direct marketing.
