text: The right to data portability shall not apply to processing necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller.

context: At the latest at the time of the first communication with the data subject, the right referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 shall be explicitly brought to the attention of the data subject and shall be presented clearly and separately from any other information.
question: When should the right to object be brought to the attention of the data subject? reference Article 21 Right to object, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: At the latest at the time of the first communication with the data subject, the right referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 shall be explicitly brought to the attention of the data subject and shall be presented clearly and separately from any other information.

context: In the cases referred to in points (a) and (c) of paragraph 2 of Article 22, the data controller shall implement suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests, at least the right to obtain human intervention on the part of the controller, to express his or her point of view and to contest the decision.
question: What measures should the data controller implement in cases referred to in points (a) and (c) of paragraph 2 of Article 22? reference Article 22 Automated individual decision-making, including profiling, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: In the cases referred to in points (a) and (c) of paragraph 2 of Article 22, the data controller shall implement suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests, at least the right to obtain human intervention on the part of the controller, to express his or her point of view and to contest the decision.

context: The objectives of general public interest of the Union or of a Member State that can justify the restriction of obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34, as well as Article 5 are in particular an important economic or financial interest of the Union or of a Member State, including monetary, budgetary and taxation a matters, public health and social security.
question: What are the objectives of general public interest of the Union or of a Member State that can justify the restriction of obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34, as well as Article 5? reference Article 23 Restrictions, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The objectives of general public interest of the Union or of a Member State that can justify the restriction of obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34, as well as Article 5 are in particular an important economic or financial interest of the Union or of a Member State, including monetary, budgetary and taxation a matters, public health and social security.

context: Where proportionate in relation to processing activities, the measures referred to in paragraph 1 shall include the implementation of appropriate data protection policies by the controller.
question: What should be included in the measures referred to in paragraph 1 of Article 24 of GDPR? reference Article 24 Responsibility of the controller, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Where proportionate in relation to processing activities, the measures referred to in paragraph 1 shall include the implementation of appropriate data protection policies by the controller.

context: The controller shall implement appropriate technical and organizational measures for ensuring that, by default, only personal data which are necessary for each specific purpose of the processing are processed.
question: What is the obligation of the controller regarding personal data processing? reference Article 25 Data protection by design and by default, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller shall implement appropriate technical and organizational measures for ensuring that, by default, only personal data which are necessary for each specific purpose of the processing are processed.

context: The arrangement between joint controllers is meant to determine their respective responsibilities for compliance with the obligations under this Regulation, in particular as regards the exercising of the rights of the data subject and their respective duties to provide the information referred to in Articles 13 and 14.
question: What is the purpose of the arrangement between joint controllers? reference Article 26 Joint controllers, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The arrangement between joint controllers is meant to determine their respective responsibilities for compliance with the obligations under this Regulation, in particular as regards the exercising of the rights of the data subject and their respective duties to provide the information referred to in Articles 13 and 14.

context: The representative should be established in one of the Member States where the data subjects, whose personal data are processed in relation to the offering of goods or services to them, or whose behaviour is monitored, are.
question: Where should the representative be established according to Article 27 of GDPR? reference Article 27 Representatives of controllers or processors not established in the Union, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The representative should be established in one of the Member States where the data subjects, whose personal data are processed in relation to the offering of goods or services to them, or whose behaviour is monitored, are.

context: Where a processor engages another processor for carrying out specific processing activities on behalf of the controller, the same data protection obligations as set out in the contract or other legal act between the controller and the processor as referred to in paragraph 3 shall be imposed on that other processor by way of a contract or other legal act under Union or Member State law, in particular providing sufficient guarantees to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures in such a manner that the processing will meet the requirements of this Regulation. Where that other processor fails to fulfill its data protection obligations, the initial processor shall remain fully liable to the controller for the performance of that other processor's obligations.
question: What is the liability of an initial processor if another processor fails to fulfill its data protection obligations? reference Article 28 Processor, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Where a processor engages another processor for carrying out specific processing activities on behalf of the controller, the same data protection obligations as set out in the contract or other legal act between the controller and the processor as referred to in paragraph 3 shall be imposed on that other processor by way of a contract or other legal act under Union or Member State law, in particular providing sufficient guarantees to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures in such a manner that the processing will meet the requirements of this Regulation. Where that other processor fails to fulfill its data protection obligations, the initial processor shall remain fully liable to the controller for the performance of that other processor's obligations.

context: The processor can process personal data without instructions from the controller if required to do so by Union or Member State law.
question: Under what circumstances can the processor process personal data without instructions from the controller? reference Article 29 Processing under the authority of the controller or processor, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The processor can process personal data without instructions from the controller if required to do so by Union or Member State law.

context: The record of processing activities maintained by the processor should include the name and contact details of the processor and each controller on behalf of which the processor is acting, categories of processing carried out on behalf of each controller, transfers of personal data, and technical and organizational security measures.
question: What information should be included in the record of processing activities maintained by the processor? reference Article 30 Records of processing activities, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The record of processing activities maintained by the processor should include the name and contact details of the processor and each controller on behalf of which the processor is acting, categories of processing carried out on behalf of each controller, transfers of personal data, and technical and organizational security measures.

context: The supervisory authority.
question: Who can request cooperation with the supervisory authority? reference Article 31 Cooperation with the supervisory authority, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The supervisory authority.

context: An approved code of conduct or an approved certification mechanism according to Article 32 may be used as an element by which to demonstrate compliance with the requirements set out in paragraph 1 of this Article.
question: What is the role of an approved code of conduct or an approved certification mechanism according to Article 32? reference Article 32 Security of processing, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: An approved code of conduct or an approved certification mechanism according to Article 32 may be used as an element by which to demonstrate compliance with the requirements set out in paragraph 1 of this Article.

context: Where, and in so far as, it is not possible to provide the information at the same time, the information may be provided in phases without undue further delay.
question: What should be done if it is not possible to provide all the information about a personal data breach at the same time? reference Article 33 Notification of a personal data breach to the supervisory authority, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Where, and in so far as, it is not possible to provide the information at the same time, the information may be provided in phases without undue further delay.

context: If the controller has not already communicated the personal data breach to the data subject, the supervisory authority, having considered the likelihood of the personal data breach resulting in a high risk, may require it to do so or may decide that any of the conditions referred to in paragraph 3 are met.
question: What is the consequence if the controller has not communicated the personal data breach to the data subject? reference Article 34 Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: If the controller has not already communicated the personal data breach to the data subject, the supervisory authority, having considered the likelihood of the personal data breach resulting in a high risk, may require it to do so or may decide that any of the conditions referred to in paragraph 3 are met.

context: The supervisory authority shall establish and make public a list of the kind of processing operations which are subject to the requirement for a data protection impact assessment pursuant to paragraph 1. The supervisory authority shall communicate those lists to the Board referred to in Article 68.
question: What is the role of the supervisory authority in relation to data protection impact assessments? reference Article 35 Data protection impact assessment, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The supervisory authority shall establish and make public a list of the kind of processing operations which are subject to the requirement for a data protection impact assessment pursuant to paragraph 1. The supervisory authority shall communicate those lists to the Board referred to in Article 68.

context: Within a period of up to eight weeks of receipt of the request for consultation.
question: What is the time period for the supervisory authority to provide written advice to the controller? reference Article 36 Prior consultation, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Within a period of up to eight weeks of receipt of the request for consultation.

context: In cases other than those referred to in paragraph 1, the controller or processor or associations and other bodies representing categories of controllers or processors may or, where required by Union or Member State law shall, designate a data protection officer.
question: Who can designate a data protection officer in cases other than those referred to in paragraph 1? reference Article 37 Designation of the data protection officer, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: In cases other than those referred to in paragraph 1, the controller or processor or associations and other bodies representing categories of controllers or processors may or, where required by Union or Member State law shall, designate a data protection officer.

context: The data protection officer is responsible for cooperating with the supervisory authority and acting as the contact point for the supervisory authority on issues relating to processing, including the prior consultation referred to in Article 36, and to consult, where appropriate, with regard to any other matter.
question: What is the responsibility of the data protection officer in relation to the supervisory authority? reference Article 39 Tasks of the data protection officer, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The data protection officer is responsible for cooperating with the supervisory authority and acting as the contact point for the supervisory authority on issues relating to processing, including the prior consultation referred to in Article 36, and to consult, where appropriate, with regard to any other matter.

context: Data subjects should contact the data protection officer with regard to all issues related to processing of their personal data and to the exercise of their rights under GDPR.
question: Who should data subjects contact with regard to all issues related to processing of their personal data and to the exercise of their rights under GDPR? reference Article 38 Position of the data protection officer, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Data subjects should contact the data protection officer with regard to all issues related to processing of their personal data and to the exercise of their rights under GDPR.

context: Codes of conduct approved pursuant to paragraph 5 of Article 40 and having general validity pursuant to paragraph 9 of Article 40 may be adhered to by controllers or processors that are not subject to GDPR pursuant to Article 3 in order to provide appropriate safeguards within the framework of personal data transfers to third countries or international organisations under the terms referred to in point (e) of Article 46(2).
question: What is the purpose of codes of conduct approved pursuant to paragraph 5 of Article 40? reference Article 40 Codes of conduct, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Codes of conduct approved pursuant to paragraph 5 of Article 40 and having general validity pursuant to paragraph 9 of Article 40 may be adhered to by controllers or processors that are not subject to GDPR pursuant to Article 3 in order to provide appropriate safeguards within the framework of personal data transfers to third countries or international organisations under the terms referred to in point (e) of Article 46(2).

context: The competent supervisory authority shall submit the draft criteria for accreditation of a body as referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article to the Board pursuant to the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63.
question: What is the role of the competent supervisory authority in accrediting a body to monitor compliance with a code of conduct? reference Article 41 Monitoring of approved codes of conduct, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The competent supervisory authority shall submit the draft criteria for accreditation of a body as referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article to the Board pursuant to the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63.

context: A certification pursuant to Article 42 does not reduce the responsibility of the controller or the processor for compliance with GDPR.
question: Does a certification pursuant to Article 42 reduce the responsibility of the controller or the processor for compliance with GDPR? reference Article 42 Certification, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: A certification pursuant to Article 42 does not reduce the responsibility of the controller or the processor for compliance with GDPR.

context: Article 10 of GDPR specifies the conditions under which personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences can be processed.
question: What is the purpose of Article 10 of GDPR? reference Article 10 Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Article 10 of GDPR specifies the conditions under which personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences can be processed.

context: Chapter 5 of the GDPR applies to any transfer of personal data which are undergoing processing or are intended for processing after transfer to a third country or to an international organization.
question: What is the scope of Chapter 5 of the GDPR? reference Article 44 General principle for transfers, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: Chapter 5 of the GDPR applies to any transfer of personal data which are undergoing processing or are intended for processing after transfer to a third country or to an international organization.

context: Certification bodies must demonstrate, to the satisfaction of the competent supervisory authority, that their tasks and duties do not result in a conflict of interests.
question: What must certification bodies demonstrate to the competent supervisory authority under GDPR? reference Article 43 Certification bodies, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Certification bodies must demonstrate, to the satisfaction of the competent supervisory authority, that their tasks and duties do not result in a conflict of interests.

context: The Commission shall, on an ongoing basis, monitor developments in third countries and international organizations that could affect the functioning of decisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 3 of this Article and decisions adopted on the basis of Article 25(6) of Directive 95/46/EC.
question: What is the role of the Commission in monitoring developments in third countries and international organizations? reference Article 45 Transfers on the basis of an adequacy decision, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: The Commission shall, on an ongoing basis, monitor developments in third countries and international organizations that could affect the functioning of decisions adopted pursuant to paragraph 3 of this Article and decisions adopted on the basis of Article 25(6) of Directive 95/46/EC.

context: The consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63 is used by the supervisory authority to apply the appropriate safeguards referred to in paragraph 1 in the cases referred to in paragraph 3 of this Article.
question: What is the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63 used for? reference Article 46 Transfers subject to appropriate safeguards, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: The consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63 is used by the supervisory authority to apply the appropriate safeguards referred to in paragraph 1 in the cases referred to in paragraph 3 of this Article.

context: An international agreement, such as a mutual legal assistance treaty, in force between the requesting third country and the Union or a Member State is a condition for the recognition or enforceability of a judgment of a court or tribunal or decision of an administrative authority of a third country.
question: What is the effect of an international agreement on the recognition or enforceability of a judgment of a court or tribunal or decision of an administrative authority of a third country? reference Article 48 Transfers or disclosures not authorised by Union law, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: An international agreement, such as a mutual legal assistance treaty, in force between the requesting third country and the Union or a Member State is a condition for the recognition or enforceability of a judgment of a court or tribunal or decision of an administrative authority of a third country.

context: The mechanisms for ensuring corrective actions to protect the rights of the data subject specified in point (j) of paragraph 2 of Article 47 are intended to ensure that any breaches of the binding corporate rules are addressed and that the rights of data subjects are protected.
question: What is the purpose of the mechanisms for ensuring corrective actions to protect the rights of the data subject specified in point (j) of paragraph 2 of Article 47? reference Article 47 Binding corporate rules, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: The mechanisms for ensuring corrective actions to protect the rights of the data subject specified in point (j) of paragraph 2 of Article 47 are intended to ensure that any breaches of the binding corporate rules are addressed and that the rights of data subjects are protected.

context: Activities carried out by public authorities in the exercise of their public powers are exempted from points (a), (b) and (c) of the first subparagraph of paragraph 1 and the second subparagraph thereof.
question: What activities are exempted from points (a), (b) and (c) of the first subparagraph of paragraph 1 and the second subparagraph thereof? reference Article 49 Derogations for specific situations, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: Activities carried out by public authorities in the exercise of their public powers are exempted from points (a), (b) and (c) of the first subparagraph of paragraph 1 and the second subparagraph thereof.

context: The appropriate safeguards for the protection of personal data and other fundamental rights and freedoms in international mutual assistance are subject to appropriate safeguards.
question: What are the appropriate safeguards for the protection of personal data and other fundamental rights and freedoms in international mutual assistance? reference Article 50 International cooperation for the protection of personal data, Chapter 5 Transfers of personal data to third countries or international organisations

text: The appropriate safeguards for the protection of personal data and other fundamental rights and freedoms in international mutual assistance are subject to appropriate safeguards.

context: If a Member State has more than one supervisory authority, it should designate the supervisory authority which is to represent those authorities in the Board and set out the mechanism to ensure compliance by the other authorities with the rules relating to the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63.
question: What should a Member State do if it has more than one supervisory authority? reference Article 51 Supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: If a Member State has more than one supervisory authority, it should designate the supervisory authority which is to represent those authorities in the Board and set out the mechanism to ensure compliance by the other authorities with the rules relating to the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63.

context: Each Member State shall ensure that each supervisory authority is provided with the human, technical and financial resources, premises and infrastructure necessary for the effective performance of its tasks and exercise of its powers, including those to be carried out in the context of mutual assistance, cooperation and participation in the Board.
question: What is the responsibility of each Member State with regards to the resources of each supervisory authority? reference Article 52 Independence, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Each Member State shall ensure that each supervisory authority is provided with the human, technical and financial resources, premises and infrastructure necessary for the effective performance of its tasks and exercise of its powers, including those to be carried out in the context of mutual assistance, cooperation and participation in the Board.

context: A member of the supervisory authority shall be dismissed only in cases of serious misconduct or if the member no longer fulfils the conditions required for the performance of the duties.
question: Under what circumstances can a member of the supervisory authority be dismissed? reference Article 53 General conditions for the members of the supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: A member of the supervisory authority shall be dismissed only in cases of serious misconduct or if the member no longer fulfils the conditions required for the performance of the duties.

context: The member or members and the staff of each supervisory authority shall, in accordance with Union or Member State law, be subject to a duty of professional secrecy both during and after their term of office, with regard to any confidential information which has come to their knowledge in the course of the performance of their tasks or exercise of their powers. During their term of office, that duty of professional secrecy shall in particular apply to reporting by natural persons of infringements of this Regulation.
question: What is the duty of professional secrecy according to Article 54? reference Article 54 Rules on the establishment of the supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: The member or members and the staff of each supervisory authority shall, in accordance with Union or Member State law, be subject to a duty of professional secrecy both during and after their term of office, with regard to any confidential information which has come to their knowledge in the course of the performance of their tasks or exercise of their powers. During their term of office, that duty of professional secrecy shall in particular apply to reporting by natural persons of infringements of this Regulation.

context: No, supervisory authorities shall not be competent to supervise processing operations of courts acting in their judicial capacity.
question: Can supervisory authorities supervise processing operations of courts acting in their judicial capacity? reference Article 55 Competence, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: No, supervisory authorities shall not be competent to supervise processing operations of courts acting in their judicial capacity.

context: The procedure provided in Article 60 shall apply. The supervisory authority which informed the lead supervisory authority may submit to the lead supervisory authority a draft for a decision. The lead supervisory authority shall take utmost account of that draft when preparing the draft decision referred to in Article 60(3).
question: What happens if the lead supervisory authority decides to handle a case? reference Article 56 Competence of the lead supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: The procedure provided in Article 60 shall apply. The supervisory authority which informed the lead supervisory authority may submit to the lead supervisory authority a draft for a decision. The lead supervisory authority shall take utmost account of that draft when preparing the draft decision referred to in Article 60(3).

context: The responsibility of supervisory authorities in handling complaints lodged by a data subject is to investigate, to the extent appropriate, the subject matter of the complaint and inform the complainant of the progress and the outcome of the investigation within a reasonable period, in particular if further investigation or coordination with another supervisory authority is necessary.
question: What is the responsibility of supervisory authorities in handling complaints lodged by a data subject? reference Article 57 Tasks, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: The responsibility of supervisory authorities in handling complaints lodged by a data subject is to investigate, to the extent appropriate, the subject matter of the complaint and inform the complainant of the progress and the outcome of the investigation within a reasonable period, in particular if further investigation or coordination with another supervisory authority is necessary.

context: The exercise of the powers conferred on the supervisory authority pursuant to this Article shall be subject to appropriate safeguards, including effective judicial remedy and due process, set out in Union and Member State law in accordance with the Charter.
question: What are the safeguards for the exercise of powers conferred on the supervisory authority according to GDPR? reference Article 58 Powers, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: The exercise of the powers conferred on the supervisory authority pursuant to this Article shall be subject to appropriate safeguards, including effective judicial remedy and due process, set out in Union and Member State law in accordance with the Charter.

context: Yes, the annual report required by Article 59 is made available to the public, to the Commission, and to the Board.
question: Is the annual report required by Article 59 made available to the public? reference Article 59 Activity reports, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Yes, the annual report required by Article 59 is made available to the public, to the Commission, and to the Board.

context: Where any of the other supervisory authorities concerned within a period of four weeks after having been consulted in accordance with paragraph 3 of this Article, expresses a relevant and reasoned objection to the draft decision, the lead supervisory authority shall, if it does not follow the relevant and reasoned objection or is of the opinion that the objection is not relevant or reasoned, submit the matter to the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63.
question: What happens if any of the other supervisory authorities concerned objects to the draft decision submitted by the lead supervisory authority? reference Article 60 Cooperation between the lead supervisory authority and the other supervisory authorities concerned, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: Where any of the other supervisory authorities concerned within a period of four weeks after having been consulted in accordance with paragraph 3 of this Article, expresses a relevant and reasoned objection to the draft decision, the lead supervisory authority shall, if it does not follow the relevant and reasoned objection or is of the opinion that the objection is not relevant or reasoned, submit the matter to the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63.

context: According to GDPR, the requested supervisory authority shall not refuse to comply with the request unless it is not competent for the subject-matter of the request or for the measures it is requested to execute, or compliance with the request would infringe this Regulation or Union or Member State law to which the supervisory authority receiving the request is subject.
question: Under what circumstances can a requested supervisory authority refuse to comply with a request according to GDPR? reference Article 61 Mutual assistance, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: According to GDPR, the requested supervisory authority shall not refuse to comply with the request unless it is not competent for the subject-matter of the request or for the measures it is requested to execute, or compliance with the request would infringe this Regulation or Union or Member State law to which the supervisory authority receiving the request is subject.

context: The purpose of the consistency mechanism in GDPR is to contribute to the consistent application of this Regulation throughout the Union.
question: What is the purpose of the consistency mechanism in GDPR? reference Article 63 Consistency mechanism, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The purpose of the consistency mechanism in GDPR is to contribute to the consistent application of this Regulation throughout the Union.

context: A supervisory authority may, in accordance with Member State law, and with the seconding supervisory authority's authorisation, confer powers, including investigative powers on the seconding supervisory authority's members or staff involved in joint operations or, in so far as the law of the Member State of the host supervisory authority permits, allow the seconding supervisory authority's members or staff to exercise their investigative powers in accordance with the law of the Member State of the seconding supervisory authority.
question: What powers can a supervisory authority confer on the seconding supervisory authority's members or staff involved in joint operations? reference Article 62 Joint operations of supervisory authorities, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: A supervisory authority may, in accordance with Member State law, and with the seconding supervisory authority's authorisation, confer powers, including investigative powers on the seconding supervisory authority's members or staff involved in joint operations or, in so far as the law of the Member State of the host supervisory authority permits, allow the seconding supervisory authority's members or staff to exercise their investigative powers in accordance with the law of the Member State of the seconding supervisory authority.

context: Supervisory authorities and the Commission should communicate any relevant information, including a summary of the facts, the draft decision, the grounds which make the enactment of such measure necessary, and the views of other supervisory authorities concerned, by electronic means to the Board using a standardized format.
question: What information should supervisory authorities and the Commission communicate to the Board? reference Article 64 Opinion of the Board, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: Supervisory authorities and the Commission should communicate any relevant information, including a summary of the facts, the draft decision, the grounds which make the enactment of such measure necessary, and the views of other supervisory authorities concerned, by electronic means to the Board using a standardized format.

context: If a supervisory authority considers that final measures need urgently be adopted, it may request an urgent opinion or an urgent binding decision from the Board, giving reasons for requesting such opinion or decision.
question: What can a supervisory authority do if it considers that final measures need urgently be adopted? reference Article 66 Urgency procedure, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: If a supervisory authority considers that final measures need urgently be adopted, it may request an urgent opinion or an urgent binding decision from the Board, giving reasons for requesting such opinion or decision.

context: The examination procedure referred to in Article 93(2) of GDPR is the procedure for adopting implementing acts of general scope.
question: What is the examination procedure referred to in Article 93(2) of GDPR? reference Article 67 Exchange of information, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The examination procedure referred to in Article 93(2) of GDPR is the procedure for adopting implementing acts of general scope.

context: Where the Board has been unable to adopt a decision within the periods referred to in paragraph 2 of Article 65, it shall adopt its decision within two weeks following the expiration of the second month referred to in paragraph 2 by a simple majority of the members of the Board.
question: What happens if the Board has been unable to adopt a decision within the periods referred to in paragraph 2 of Article 65? reference Article 65 Dispute resolution by the Board, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: Where the Board has been unable to adopt a decision within the periods referred to in paragraph 2 of Article 65, it shall adopt its decision within two weeks following the expiration of the second month referred to in paragraph 2 by a simple majority of the members of the Board.

context: When more than one supervisory authority is responsible for monitoring the application of GDPR in a Member State, a joint representative shall be appointed in accordance with that Member State's law.
question: What happens when more than one supervisory authority is responsible for monitoring the application of GDPR in a Member State? reference Article 68 European Data Protection Board, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: When more than one supervisory authority is responsible for monitoring the application of GDPR in a Member State, a joint representative shall be appointed in accordance with that Member State's law.

context: The exceptions to the Board seeking or taking instructions from anyone are requests by the Commission referred to in point (b) of Article 70(1) and in Article 70(2), according to Article 69(2) of GDPR.
question: What are the exceptions to the Board seeking or taking instructions from anyone? reference Article 69 Independence, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The exceptions to the Board seeking or taking instructions from anyone are requests by the Commission referred to in point (b) of Article 70(1) and in Article 70(2), according to Article 69(2) of GDPR.

context: The guidelines, recommendations, and best practices issued by the Board aim to encourage consistent application of the GDPR.
question: What is the purpose of the guidelines, recommendations, and best practices issued by the Board? reference Article 70 Tasks of the Board, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The guidelines, recommendations, and best practices issued by the Board aim to encourage consistent application of the GDPR.

context: The annual report mentioned in Article 71 of GDPR should include a review of the practical application of the guidelines, recommendations, and best practices referred to in point (l) of Article 70(1) as well as of the binding decisions referred to in Article 65.
question: What should be included in the annual report mentioned in Article 71 of GDPR? reference Article 71 Reports, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The annual report mentioned in Article 71 of GDPR should include a review of the practical application of the guidelines, recommendations, and best practices referred to in point (l) of Article 70(1) as well as of the binding decisions referred to in Article 65.

context: The Board referred to in this article is the European Data Protection Board (EDPB).
question: What is the Board referred to in this article? reference Article 72 Procedure, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The Board referred to in this article is the European Data Protection Board (EDPB).

context: Yes, the term of office of the Chair and of the deputy chairs shall be renewable once.
question: Can the term of office for the Chair and deputy chairs be renewed? reference Article 73 Chair, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: Yes, the term of office of the Chair and of the deputy chairs shall be renewable once.

context: The role of the deputy chairs in the Board is determined by the allocation of tasks laid down in the Board's rules of procedure.
question: What is the role of the deputy chairs in the Board? reference Article 74 Tasks of the Chair, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The role of the deputy chairs in the Board is determined by the allocation of tasks laid down in the Board's rules of procedure.

context: The Memorandum of Understanding is established and published by the Board and the European Data Protection Supervisor to determine the terms of their cooperation and applicable to the staff of the European Data Protection Supervisor involved in carrying out the tasks conferred on the Board by this Regulation.
question: What is the purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding? reference Article 75 Secretariat, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The Memorandum of Understanding is established and published by the Board and the European Data Protection Supervisor to determine the terms of their cooperation and applicable to the staff of the European Data Protection Supervisor involved in carrying out the tasks conferred on the Board by this Regulation.

context: Regarding public access to European Parliament, Council and Commission documents.
question: What is the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council? reference Article 76 Confidentiality, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: Regarding public access to European Parliament, Council and Commission documents.

context: A data subject should lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority if he or she considers that the processing of personal data relating to him or her infringes GDPR.
question: What should a data subject do if he or she considers that the processing of personal data relating to him or her infringes GDPR? reference Article 77 Right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: A data subject should lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority if he or she considers that the processing of personal data relating to him or her infringes GDPR.

context: Proceedings against a supervisory authority shall be brought before the courts of the Member State where the supervisory authority is established.
question: What is the jurisdiction for proceedings against a supervisory authority according to Article 78 of GDPR? reference Article 78 Right to an effective judicial remedy against a supervisory authority, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: Proceedings against a supervisory authority shall be brought before the courts of the Member State where the supervisory authority is established.

context: An administrative or non-judicial remedy refers to the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority pursuant to Article 77. A judicial remedy, on the other hand, refers to the right to bring proceedings against a controller or processor before a court of law.
question: What is the difference between an administrative remedy and a judicial remedy under GDPR? reference Article 79 Right to an effective judicial remedy against a controller or processor, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: An administrative or non-judicial remedy refers to the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority pursuant to Article 77. A judicial remedy, on the other hand, refers to the right to bring proceedings against a controller or processor before a court of law.

context: The body, organisation or association referred to in paragraph 2 of Article 80 has the right to lodge a complaint with the supervisory authority which is competent pursuant to Article 77 and to exercise the rights referred to in Articles 78 and 79 if it considers that the rights of a data subject under this Regulation have been infringed as a result of the processing, independently of a data subject's mandate.
question: What is the right of the body, organisation or association referred to in paragraph 2 of Article 80? reference Article 80 Representation of data subjects, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: The body, organisation or association referred to in paragraph 2 of Article 80 has the right to lodge a complaint with the supervisory authority which is competent pursuant to Article 77 and to exercise the rights referred to in Articles 78 and 79 if it considers that the rights of a data subject under this Regulation have been infringed as a result of the processing, independently of a data subject's mandate.

context: If proceedings concerning the same subject matter as regards processing of the same controller or processor are pending at first instance, any court other than the court first seized may, on the application of one of the parties, decline jurisdiction if the court first seized has jurisdiction over the actions in question and its law permits the consolidation thereof.
question: Under what circumstances can any court other than the court first seized decline jurisdiction if the court first seized has jurisdiction over the actions in question and its law permits the consolidation thereof? reference Article 81 Suspension of proceedings, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: If proceedings concerning the same subject matter as regards processing of the same controller or processor are pending at first instance, any court other than the court first seized may, on the application of one of the parties, decline jurisdiction if the court first seized has jurisdiction over the actions in question and its law permits the consolidation thereof.

context: Where more than one controller or processor, or both a controller and a processor, are involved in the same processing and where they are, under paragraphs 2 and 3, responsible for any damage caused by processing, each controller or processor shall be held liable for the entire damage in order to ensure effective compensation of the data subject.
question: What happens when more than one controller or processor are responsible for damage caused by processing? reference Article 82 Right to compensation and liability, Chapter 8 Remedies, liability and penalties

text: Where more than one controller or processor, or both a controller and a processor, are involved in the same processing and where they are, under paragraphs 2 and 3, responsible for any damage caused by processing, each controller or processor shall be held liable for the entire damage in order to ensure effective compensation of the data subject.

context: Non-compliance with an order by the supervisory authority as referred to in Article 58(2) shall be subject to administrative fines up to 20 000 000 EUR, or in the case of an undertaking, up to 4 % of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher.

text: Non-compliance with an order by the supervisory authority as referred to in Article 58(2) shall be subject to administrative fines up to 20 000 000 EUR, or in the case of an undertaking, up to 4 % of the total worldwide annual turnover of the preceding financial year, whichever is higher.

context: If there is any subsequent amendment affecting the provisions of its law pursuant to paragraph 1 of Article 84, each Member State shall notify to the Commission without delay.

text: If there is any subsequent amendment affecting the provisions of its law pursuant to paragraph 1 of Article 84, each Member State shall notify to the Commission without delay.

context: Member States can provide exemptions or derogations from Chapter II (principles), Chapter III (rights of the data subject), Chapter IV (controller and processor), Chapter V (transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations), Chapter VI (independent supervisory authorities), Chapter VII (cooperation and consistency) and Chapter IX (specific data processing situations) for processing carried out for journalistic purposes or the purpose of academic artistic or literary expression.

text: Member States can provide exemptions or derogations from Chapter II (principles), Chapter III (rights of the data subject), Chapter IV (controller and processor), Chapter V (transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations), Chapter VI (independent supervisory authorities), Chapter VII (cooperation and consistency) and Chapter IX (specific data processing situations) for processing carried out for journalistic purposes or the purpose of academic artistic or literary expression.

text: The measures included in the rules provided by Member States or collective agreements should safeguard the data subject's human dignity, legitimate interests, and fundamental rights.

context: The national identification number or any other identifier of general application shall be used only under appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject pursuant to this Regulation.

text: The national identification number or any other identifier of general application shall be used only under appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject pursuant to this Regulation.

context: The purpose of GDPR is to protect the personal data of individuals within the European Union.

text: The purpose of GDPR is to protect the personal data of individuals within the European Union.

context: For processing personal data for archiving purposes in the public interest, derogations can be made from the rights referred to in Articles 15, 16, 18, 19, 20 and 21 subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in paragraph 1 of Article 89, in so far as such rights are likely to render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the specific purposes, and such derogations are necessary for the fulfilment of those purposes.
question: What rights can be subject to derogations for processing personal data for archiving purposes in the public interest? reference Article 89 Safeguards and derogations relating to processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes, Chapter 9 Provisions relating to specific processing situations

text: For processing personal data for archiving purposes in the public interest, derogations can be made from the rights referred to in Articles 15, 16, 18, 19, 20 and 21 subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in paragraph 1 of Article 89, in so far as such rights are likely to render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the specific purposes, and such derogations are necessary for the fulfilment of those purposes.

context: The rules adopted by Member States pursuant to paragraph 1 of Article 90 shall apply only with regard to personal data which the controller or processor has received as a result of or has obtained in an activity covered by that obligation of secrecy.

text: The rules adopted by Member States pursuant to paragraph 1 of Article 90 shall apply only with regard to personal data which the controller or processor has received as a result of or has obtained in an activity covered by that obligation of secrecy.

text: They shall be subject to the supervision of an independent supervisory authority.

context: A decision of revocation shall put an end to the delegation of power specified in that decision. It shall not affect the validity of any delegated acts already in force.
question: What happens when a decision of revocation is made according to Article 92 of GDPR? reference Article 92 Exercise of the delegation, Chapter 10 Delegated acts and implementing acts

text: A decision of revocation shall put an end to the delegation of power specified in that decision. It shall take effect the day following that of its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union or at a later date specified therein. It shall not affect the validity of any delegated acts already in force.

context: When reference is made to paragraph 3 of Article 93 of GDPR, Article 8 of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011, in conjunction with Article 5 thereof, applies.

text: When reference is made to paragraph 3 of Article 93 of GDPR, Article 8 of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011, in conjunction with Article 5 thereof, applies.

text: The objective of Directive 2002/58/EC is to ensure the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms, and in particular the right to privacy, with respect to the processing of personal data in the electronic communication sector.

context: The agreements mentioned in Article 96 of GDPR shall remain in force until amended, replaced or revoked.

text: The agreements mentioned in Article 96 of GDPR shall remain in force until amended, replaced or revoked.

text: For the purpose of paragraph 1 of Article 97 of GDPR, the Commission may request information from Member States and supervisory authorities.

context: The reason for amending other Union legal acts on data protection is to ensure uniform and consistent protection of natural persons with regard to processing.

text: The reason for amending other Union legal acts on data protection is to ensure uniform and consistent protection of natural persons with regard to processing.

context: Personal data protection is important under GDPR as it protects the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons.

text: Personal data protection is important under GDPR as it protects the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons.

context: GDPR applies to the processing of personal data wholly or partly by automated means and to the processing other than by automated means of personal data which form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system.

text: GDPR applies to the processing of personal data wholly or partly by automated means and to the processing other than by automated means of personal data which form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system.

context: Article 3(1) applies to the processing of personal data in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the Union, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not. Article 3(2) applies to the processing of personal data of data subjects who are in the Union by a controller or processor not established in the Union, where the processing activities are related to the offering of goods or services to such data subjects in the Union or the monitoring of their behavior as far as their behavior takes place within the Union.
question: What is the difference between the territorial scope of GDPR in Article 3(1) and Article 3(2)? reference Article 3 Territorial scope, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: Article 3(1) applies to the processing of personal data in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the Union, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not. Article 3(2) applies to the processing of personal data of data subjects who are in the Union by a controller or processor not established in the Union, where the processing activities are related to the offering of goods or services to such data subjects in the Union or the monitoring of their behavior as far as their behavior takes place within the Union.

context: Controller means the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data; where the purposes and means of such processing are determined by Union or Member State law, the controller or the specific criteria for its nomination may be provided for by Union or Member State law.
question: What is the definition of controller according to GDPR? reference Article 4 Definitions, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: Controller means the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data; where the purposes and means of such processing are determined by Union or Member State law, the controller or the specific criteria for its nomination may be provided for by Union or Member State law.

context: 'Cross-border processing' means either: (a) processing of personal data which takes place in the context of the activities of establishments in more than one Member State of a controller or processor in the Union where the controller or processor is established in more than one Member State; or (b) processing of personal data which takes place in the context of the activities of a single establishment of a controller or processor in the Union but which substantially affects or is likely to substantially affect data subjects in more than one Member State.
question: What is the definition of 'cross-border processing' according to GDPR? reference Article 4 Definitions, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: 'Cross-border processing' means either: (a) processing of personal data which takes place in the context of the activities of establishments in more than one Member State of a controller or processor in the Union where the controller or processor is established in more than one Member State; or (b) processing of personal data which takes place in the context of the activities of a single establishment of a controller or processor in the Union but which substantially affects or is likely to substantially affect data subjects in more than one Member State.

context: The principle of storage limitation states that personal data should be kept in a form which permits identification of data subjects for no longer than is necessary for the purposes for which the personal data are processed; personal data may be stored for longer periods insofar as the personal data will be processed solely for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes in accordance with Article 89(1) subject to implementation of the appropriate technical and organisational measures required by this Regulation in order to safeguard the rights and freedoms of the data subject.
question: What does the principle of storage limitation state? reference Article 5 Principles relating to processing of personal data, Chapter 2 Principles

text: The principle of storage limitation states that personal data should be kept in a form which permits identification of data subjects for no longer than is necessary for the purposes for which the personal data are processed; personal data may be stored for longer periods insofar as the personal data will be processed solely for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes in accordance with Article 89(1) subject to implementation of the appropriate technical and organisational measures required by this Regulation in order to safeguard the rights and freedoms of the data subject.

context: The purpose of the legal basis that may contain specific provisions to adapt the application of rules of GDPR is to determine the general conditions governing the lawfulness of processing by the controller; the types of data which are subject to the processing; the data subjects concerned; the entities to, and the purposes for which, the personal data may be disclosed; the purpose limitation; storage periods; and processing operations and processing procedures, including measures to ensure lawful and fair processing such as those for other specific processing situations as provided for in Chapter IX.
question: What is the purpose of the legal basis that may contain specific provisions to adapt the application of rules of GDPR? reference Article 6 Lawfulness of processing, Chapter 2 Principles

text: The purpose of the legal basis that may contain specific provisions to adapt the application of rules of GDPR is to determine the general conditions governing the lawfulness of processing by the controller; the types of data which are subject to the processing; the data subjects concerned; the entities to, and the purposes for which, the personal data may be disclosed; the purpose limitation; storage periods; and processing operations and processing procedures, including measures to ensure lawful and fair processing such as those for other specific processing situations as provided for in Chapter IX.

context: Where processing is based on consent, the controller shall be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consented to processing of his or her personal data.

text: Where processing is based on consent, the controller shall be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consented to processing of his or her personal data.

text: Processing personal data of a child who is at least 16 years old in relation to information society services shall be lawful.

context: Processing of personal data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation is allowed if the data subject has given explicit consent to the processing of those personal data for one or more specified purposes, except where Union or Member State law provide that the prohibition referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the data subject.
question: What is the exception to the prohibition of processing personal data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation? reference Article 9 Processing of special categories of personal data, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Processing of personal data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation is allowed if the data subject has given explicit consent to the processing of those personal data for one or more specified purposes, except where Union or Member State law provide that the prohibition referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the data subject.

context: The exception to the rule is when the data subject, for the purpose of exercising his or her rights under Articles 15 to 20, provides additional information enabling his or her identification.

text: The exception to the rule is when the data subject, for the purpose of exercising his or her rights under Articles 15 to 20, provides additional information enabling his or her identification.

context: The controller shall provide information on action taken on a request under Articles 15 to 22 to the data subject without undue delay and in any event within one month of receipt of the request. That period may be extended by two further months where necessary, taking into account the complexity and number of the requests.
question: What is the time limit for the controller to provide information on a request under Articles 15 to 22 to the data subject? reference Article 12 Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller shall provide information on action taken on a request under Articles 15 to 22 to the data subject without undue delay and in any event within one month of receipt of the request. That period may be extended by two further months where necessary, taking into account the complexity and number of the requests.

context: The purpose of providing a data subject with information on the recipients or categories of recipients of their personal data is to ensure transparency and accountability in the processing of personal data.
question: What is the purpose of providing a data subject with information on the recipients or categories of recipients of their personal data? reference Article 13 Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The purpose of providing a data subject with information on the recipients or categories of recipients of their personal data is to ensure transparency and accountability in the processing of personal data.

context: Paragraphs 1 to 4 shall not apply where and insofar as: the data subject already has the information; the provision of such information proves impossible or would involve a disproportionate effort, in particular for processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes, subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in Article 89(1) or in so far as the obligation referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article is likely to render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the objectives of that processing. In such cases the controller shall take appropriate measures to protect the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests, including making the information publicly available; obtaining or disclosure is expressly laid down by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject and which provides appropriate measures to protect the data subject's legitimate interests; or where the personal data must remain confidential subject to an obligation of professional secrecy regulated by Union or Member State law, including a statutory obligation of secrecy.
question: In what circumstances do paragraphs 1 to 4 of Article 14 not apply? reference Article 14 Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: Paragraphs 1 to 4 shall not apply where and insofar as: the data subject already has the information; the provision of such information proves impossible or would involve a disproportionate effort, in particular for processing for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes, subject to the conditions and safeguards referred to in Article 89(1) or in so far as the obligation referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article is likely to render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the objectives of that processing. In such cases the controller shall take appropriate measures to protect the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests, including making the information publicly available; obtaining or disclosure is expressly laid down by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject and which provides appropriate measures to protect the data subject's legitimate interests; or where the personal data must remain confidential subject to an obligation of professional secrecy regulated by Union or Member State law, including a statutory obligation of secrecy.

context: The data subject has the right to request from the controller rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing of personal data concerning the data subject or to object to such processing.

context: The exceptions to the right to erasure are: (a) for exercising the right of freedom of expression and information; (b) for compliance with a legal obligation which requires processing by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject or for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller; (c) for reasons of public interest in the area of public health in accordance with points (h) and (i) of Article 9(2) as well as Article 9(3); (d) for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes in accordance with Article 89(1) in so far as the right referred to in paragraph 1 is likely to render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the objectives of that processing; or (e) for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims.
question: What are the exceptions to the right to erasure? reference Article 17 Right to erasure (‘right to be forgotten’), Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The exceptions to the right to erasure are: (a) for exercising the right of freedom of expression and information; (b) for compliance with a legal obligation which requires processing by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject or for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller; (c) for reasons of public interest in the area of public health in accordance with points (h) and (i) of Article 9(2) as well as Article 9(3); (d) for archiving purposes in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes in accordance with Article 89(1) in so far as the right referred to in paragraph 1 is likely to render impossible or seriously impair the achievement of the objectives of that processing; or (e) for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims.

context: Erasure means the complete deletion of personal data, while restriction of processing means the limitation of processing activities on personal data.
question: What is the difference between erasure and restriction of processing? reference Article 18 Right to restriction of processing, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: Erasure means the complete deletion of personal data, while restriction of processing means the limitation of processing activities on personal data.

context: The purpose of communicating rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing to each recipient is to ensure that the recipients are aware of the changes made to the personal data and can take appropriate action if necessary.

text: The purpose of communicating rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing to each recipient is to ensure that the recipients are aware of the changes made to the personal data and can take appropriate action if necessary.

context: The exception to the rule that decisions referred to in paragraph 2 of Article 22 shall not be based on special categories of personal data referred to in Article 9(1) is if point (a) or (g) of Article 9(2) applies and suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests are in place.

text: The representative designated according to Article 27 of GDPR is mandated by the controller or processor to be addressed in addition to or instead of the controller or the processor by, in particular, supervisory authorities and data subjects, on all issues related to processing, for the purposes of ensuring compliance with this Regulation.

context: Adherence of a processor to an approved code of conduct as referred to in Article 40 or an approved certification mechanism as referred to in Article 42 may be used as an element by which to demonstrate sufficient guarantees as referred to in paragraphs 1 and 4 of this Article.

question: What is the purpose of the communication to the data subject? reference Article 34 Communication of a personal data breach to the data subject, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

context: Yes, the supervisory authority may establish and make public a list of the kind of processing operations for which no data protection impact assessment is required. The supervisory authority shall communicate those lists to the Board.

text: The data protection officer is responsible for informing and advising the controller or the processor and the employees who carry out processing of their obligations pursuant to GDPR and to other Union or Member State data protection provisions, and for the awareness-raising and training of staff involved in processing operations.
