question: What is the definition of 'relevant and reasoned objection' according to GDPR? reference Article 4 Definitions, Chapter 1 General provisions

text: 'Relevant and reasoned objection' means an objection to a draft decision as to whether there is an infringement of this Regulation, or whether envisaged action in relation to the controller or processor complies with this Regulation, which clearly demonstrates the significance of the risks posed by the draft decision as regards the fundamental rights and freedoms of data subjects and, where applicable, the free flow of personal data within the Union.

context: The principle of integrity and confidentiality states that personal data should be processed in a manner that ensures appropriate security of the personal data, including protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage, using appropriate technical or organisational measures.
question: What does the principle of integrity and confidentiality state? reference Article 5 Principles relating to processing of personal data, Chapter 2 Principles

text: The principle of integrity and confidentiality states that personal data should be processed in a manner that ensures appropriate security of the personal data, including protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage, using appropriate technical or organisational measures.

context: When processing personal data for a purpose other than that for which the personal data have been collected, the controller should take into account, inter alia: (a) any link between the purposes for which the personal data have been collected and the purposes of the intended further processing; (b) the context in which the personal data have been collected, in particular regarding the relationship between data subjects and the controller; (c) the nature of the personal data, in particular whether special categories of personal data are processed, pursuant to Article 9, or whether personal data related to criminal convictions and offences are processed, pursuant to Article 10; (d) the possible consequences of the intended further processing for data subjects; (e) the existence of appropriate safeguards, which may include encryption or pseudonymisation.
question: What are the factors that the controller should take into account when processing personal data for a purpose other than that for which the personal data have been collected? reference Article 6 Lawfulness of processing, Chapter 2 Principles

text: When processing personal data for a purpose other than that for which the personal data have been collected, the controller should take into account, inter alia: (a) any link between the purposes for which the personal data have been collected and the purposes of the intended further processing; (b) the context in which the personal data have been collected, in particular regarding the relationship between data subjects and the controller; (c) the nature of the personal data, in particular whether special categories of personal data are processed, pursuant to Article 9, or whether personal data related to criminal convictions and offences are processed, pursuant to Article 10; (d) the possible consequences of the intended further processing for data subjects; (e) the existence of appropriate safeguards, which may include encryption or pseudonymisation.

context: Any part of such a declaration which constitutes an infringement of this Regulation shall not be binding.
question: What happens if a part of a written declaration constitutes an infringement of GDPR? reference Article 7 Conditions for consent, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Any part of such a declaration which constitutes an infringement of this Regulation shall not be binding.

context: Member States may provide by law for a lower age for those purposes provided that such lower age is not below 13 years.
question: What is the responsibility of Member States in relation to the age limit for processing personal data of a child? reference Article 8 Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Member States may provide by law for a lower age for those purposes provided that such lower age is not below 13 years.

context: Processing of genetic data is allowed if the data subject has given explicit consent to the processing of those personal data for one or more specified purposes, except where Union or Member State law provide that the prohibition referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the data subject.
question: What is the exception to the prohibition of processing genetic data? reference Article 9 Processing of special categories of personal data, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Processing of genetic data is allowed if the data subject has given explicit consent to the processing of those personal data for one or more specified purposes, except where Union or Member State law provide that the prohibition referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the data subject.

context: Article 11 of GDPR applies to processing of personal data that does not require identification of the data subject by the controller.
question: What is the scope of Article 11 of GDPR? reference Article 11 Processing which does not require identification, Chapter 2 Principles

text: Article 11 of GDPR applies to processing of personal data that does not require identification of the data subject by the controller.

context: If the controller does not take action on the request of the data subject, the controller shall inform the data subject without delay and at the latest within one month of receipt of the request of the reasons for not taking action and on the possibility of lodging a complaint with a supervisory authority and seeking a judicial remedy.
question: What should the controller do if it does not take action on the request of the data subject? reference Article 12 Transparent information, communication and modalities for the exercise of the rights of the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: If the controller does not take action on the request of the data subject, the controller shall inform the data subject without delay and at the latest within one month of receipt of the request of the reasons for not taking action and on the possibility of lodging a complaint with a supervisory authority and seeking a judicial remedy.

context: The purpose of providing a data subject with information on the legal basis for the processing of their personal data is to ensure transparency and accountability in the processing of personal data.
question: What is the purpose of providing a data subject with information on the legal basis for the processing of their personal data? reference Article 13 Information to be provided where personal data are collected from the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The purpose of providing a data subject with information on the legal basis for the processing of their personal data is to ensure transparency and accountability in the processing of personal data.

context: The controller shall provide the information referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 within a reasonable period after obtaining the personal data, but at the latest within one month, having regard to the specific circumstances in which the personal data are processed.
question: What is the maximum time limit for a controller to provide the information referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 to a data subject? reference Article 14 Information to be provided where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The controller shall provide the information referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 within a reasonable period after obtaining the personal data, but at the latest within one month, having regard to the specific circumstances in which the personal data are processed.

context: The data subject has the right to request from the controller rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing of personal data concerning the data subject or to object to such processing.
question: What is the data subject's right if the personal data are no longer necessary for the purposes for which they were collected? reference Article 15 Right of access by the data subject, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The data subject has the right to request from the controller rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing of personal data concerning the data subject or to object to such processing.

context: The data subject has the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority and to seek judicial remedy.
question: What is the right of the data subject if the controller fails to rectify inaccurate personal data under Article 16 of GDPR? reference Article 16 Right to rectification, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The data subject has the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority and to seek judicial remedy.

context: If the right to erasure does not apply, the controller shall inform the data subject of the reasons why and of the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority and to seek a judicial remedy.
question: What should the controller do if the right to erasure does not apply? reference Article 17 Right to erasure (‘right to be forgotten’), Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: If the right to erasure does not apply, the controller shall inform the data subject of the reasons why and of the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority and to seek a judicial remedy.

context: Personal data that has been restricted under Article 18 of GDPR shall only be processed with the data subject's consent or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims or for the protection of the rights of another natural or legal person or for reasons of important public interest of the Union or of a Member State, with the exception of storage.
question: Can personal data that has been restricted under Article 18 of GDPR be processed without the data subject's consent? reference Article 18 Right to restriction of processing, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: Personal data that has been restricted under Article 18 of GDPR shall only be processed with the data subject's consent or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims or for the protection of the rights of another natural or legal person or for reasons of important public interest of the Union or of a Member State, with the exception of storage.

context: The notification obligation of the controller according to Article 19 of GDPR is to communicate any rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing carried out in accordance with Article 16, Article 17(1) and Article 18 to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless this proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort.
question: What is the notification obligation of the controller according to Article 19 of GDPR? reference Article 19 Notification obligation regarding rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The notification obligation of the controller according to Article 19 of GDPR is to communicate any rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing carried out in accordance with Article 16, Article 17(1) and Article 18 to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless this proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort.

context: The right to data portability shall apply if the processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (a) of Article 9(2) or on a contract pursuant to point (b) of Article 6(1).
question: What is the exception to the exception of the right to data portability? reference Article 20 Right to data portability, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The right to data portability shall apply if the processing is based on consent pursuant to point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (a) of Article 9(2) or on a contract pursuant to point (b) of Article 6(1).

context: The data subject, on grounds relating to his or her particular situation, shall have the right to object to processing of personal data concerning him or her, unless the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out for reasons of public interest.
question: What is the exception to the right to object for scientific or historical research purposes? reference Article 21 Right to object, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The data subject, on grounds relating to his or her particular situation, shall have the right to object to processing of personal data concerning him or her, unless the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out for reasons of public interest.

context: The purpose of paragraph 2(a) of Article 22 is to allow automated decision-making if it is necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract between the data subject and a data controller.
question: What is the purpose of paragraph 2(a) of Article 22? reference Article 22 Automated individual decision-making, including profiling, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The purpose of paragraph 2(a) of Article 22 is to allow automated decision-making if it is necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract between the data subject and a data controller.

context: The purpose of the right of data subjects to be informed about the restriction is to ensure transparency and accountability.
question: What is the purpose of the right of data subjects to be informed about the restriction? reference Article 23 Restrictions, Chapter 3 Rights of the data subject

text: The purpose of the right of data subjects to be informed about the restriction is to ensure transparency and accountability.

context: To ensure and to be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with this Regulation.
question: What is the purpose of implementing appropriate technical and organisational measures according to Article 24 of GDPR? reference Article 24 Responsibility of the controller, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: To ensure and to be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with this Regulation.

context: The controller shall implement appropriate technical and organizational measures both at the time of the determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself.
question: When should the controller implement appropriate technical and organizational measures? reference Article 25 Data protection by design and by default, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The controller shall implement appropriate technical and organizational measures both at the time of the determination of the means for processing and at the time of the processing itself.

context: The essence of the arrangement between joint controllers shall be made available to the data subject.
question: What should be made available to the data subject regarding the arrangement between joint controllers? reference Article 26 Joint controllers, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The essence of the arrangement between joint controllers shall be made available to the data subject.

context: The designation of a representative by the controller or processor shall be without prejudice to legal actions which could be initiated against the controller or the processor themselves.
question: What is the scope of the legal actions that can be initiated against the controller or the processor themselves despite the designation of a representative according to Article 27 of GDPR? reference Article 27 Representatives of controllers or processors not established in the Union, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The designation of a representative by the controller or processor shall be without prejudice to legal actions which could be initiated against the controller or the processor themselves.

context: The contract or the other legal act referred to in paragraphs 3 and 4 of this Article may be based, in whole or in part, on standard contractual clauses referred to in paragraphs 7 and 8 of this Article, including when they are part of a certification granted to the controller or processor pursuant to Articles 42 and 43.
question: What is the purpose of standard contractual clauses referred to in paragraphs 7 and 8 of Article 28? reference Article 28 Processor, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The contract or the other legal act referred to in paragraphs 3 and 4 of this Article may be based, in whole or in part, on standard contractual clauses referred to in paragraphs 7 and 8 of this Article, including when they are part of a certification granted to the controller or processor pursuant to Articles 42 and 43.

context: If the processor processes personal data in a way that is not in accordance with the controller's instructions, they may be held liable for any damages that result.
question: What happens if the processor processes personal data in a way that is not in accordance with the controller's instructions? reference Article 29 Processing under the authority of the controller or processor, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: If the processor processes personal data in a way that is not in accordance with the controller's instructions, they may be held liable for any damages that result.

context: The supervisory authority can request access to the record of processing activities.

text: The supervisory authority can request access to the record of processing activities.

context: To cooperate with the supervisory authority upon request.

text: To cooperate with the supervisory authority upon request.

context: The purpose of regularly testing, assessing, and evaluating the effectiveness of technical and organizational measures according to Article 32 is to ensure that the measures remain effective over time and to identify any weaknesses or areas for improvement.
question: What is the purpose of regularly testing, assessing, and evaluating the effectiveness of technical and organizational measures according to Article 32? reference Article 32 Security of processing, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The purpose of regularly testing, assessing, and evaluating the effectiveness of technical and organizational measures according to Article 32 is to ensure that the measures remain effective over time and to identify any weaknesses or areas for improvement.

context: That documentation shall enable the supervisory authority to verify compliance with this Article.

question: What is the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63? reference Article 35 Data protection impact assessment, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: Prior to the adoption of the lists referred to in paragraphs 4 and 5, the competent supervisory authority shall apply the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63 where such lists involve processing activities which are related to the offering of goods or services to data subjects or to the monitoring of their behaviour in several Member States, or may substantially affect the free movement of personal data within the Union.

context: Yes, the data protection officer may be a staff member of the controller or processor, or fulfil the tasks on the basis of a service contract.

text: Yes, the data protection officer may be a staff member of the controller or processor, or fulfil the tasks on the basis of a service contract.

context: The data protection officer shall in the performance of his or her tasks have due regard to the risk associated with processing operations, taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing.

text: The data protection officer shall in the performance of his or her tasks have due regard to the risk associated with processing operations, taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing.

context: No, the data protection officer shall not be dismissed or penalized by the controller or the processor for performing their tasks.

text: No, the data protection officer shall not be dismissed or penalized by the controller or the processor for performing their tasks.

context: The Board shall provide an opinion on whether the draft code, amendment or extension complies with GDPR or, in the situation referred to in paragraph 3 of Article 40, provides appropriate safeguards. If the opinion confirms compliance, the Board shall submit its opinion to the Commission.
question: What is the role of the Board in approving codes of conduct? reference Article 40 Codes of conduct, Chapter 4 Controller and processor

text: The Board shall provide an opinion on whether the draft code, amendment or extension complies with GDPR or, in the situation referred to in paragraph 3 of Article 40, provides appropriate safeguards. If the opinion confirms compliance, the Board shall submit its opinion to the Commission.

context: The controller or processor which submits its processing to the certification mechanism shall provide the certification body referred to in Article 43, or where applicable, the competent supervisory authority, with all information and access to its processing activities which are necessary to conduct the certification procedure.

context: The certification bodies referred to in paragraph 1 shall provide the competent supervisory authorities with the reasons for granting or withdrawing the requested certification.

text: The Commission shall enter into consultations with the third country or international organization with a view to remedying the situation giving rise to the decision made pursuant to paragraph 5.

text: Decisions adopted by the Commission on the basis of Article 26(4) of Directive 95/46/EC shall remain in force until amended, replaced or repealed, if necessary, by a Commission Decision adopted in accordance with paragraph 2 of this Article.

text: The cooperation mechanism with the supervisory authority specified in point (l) of paragraph 2 of Article 47 is intended to ensure compliance by any member of the group of undertakings or group of enterprises engaged in a joint economic activity by making available to the supervisory authority the results of verifications of the measures referred to in point (j).

context: The controller or processor shall document the assessment as well as the suitable safeguards referred to in the second subparagraph of paragraph 1 of this Article in the records referred to in Article 30.

text: The controller or processor shall document the assessment as well as the suitable safeguards referred to in the second subparagraph of paragraph 1 of this Article in the records referred to in Article 30.

context: The purpose of promoting the exchange and documentation of personal data protection legislation and practice is to provide information on jurisdictional conflicts with third countries.

context: The purpose of the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63 is to ensure the consistent application of GDPR throughout the Union.

text: The purpose of the consistency mechanism referred to in Article 63 is to ensure the consistent application of GDPR throughout the Union.

context: Each Member State shall ensure that each supervisory authority is subject to financial control which does not affect its independence and that it has separate, public annual budgets, which may be part of the overall state or national budget.

text: Each Member State shall ensure that each supervisory authority is subject to financial control which does not affect its independence and that it has separate, public annual budgets, which may be part of the overall state or national budget.

context: The supervisory authority is responsible for monitoring the application of GDPR, promoting public awareness of the risks, rules, safeguards and rights in relation to processing, and facilitating the exercise of data subjects' rights.
question: What is the role of the supervisory authority? reference Article 53 General conditions for the members of the supervisory authority, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: The supervisory authority is responsible for monitoring the application of GDPR, promoting public awareness of the risks, rules, safeguards and rights in relation to processing, and facilitating the exercise of data subjects' rights.

context: The scope of the duty of professional secrecy according to Article 54 is any confidential information which has come to the knowledge of the member or members and the staff of each supervisory authority in the course of the performance of their tasks or exercise of their powers.

text: The scope of the duty of professional secrecy according to Article 54 is any confidential information which has come to the knowledge of the member or members and the staff of each supervisory authority in the course of the performance of their tasks or exercise of their powers.

context: Article 55 specifies the competence of supervisory authorities.
question: Which Article of GDPR specifies the competence of supervisory authorities? reference Article 55 Competence, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Article 55 specifies the competence of supervisory authorities.

context: The lead supervisory authority shall be the sole interlocutor of the controller or processor for the cross-border processing carried out by that controller or processor.

context: Each Member State may provide by law that its supervisory authority shall have additional powers to those referred to in paragraphs 1, 2, and 3. The exercise of those powers shall not impair the effective operation of Chapter VII.
question: What additional powers can each Member State provide to its supervisory authority according to GDPR? reference Article 58 Powers, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

text: Each Member State may provide by law that its supervisory authority shall have additional powers to those referred to in paragraphs 1, 2, and 3. The exercise of those powers shall not impair the effective operation of Chapter VII.

context: The annual report required by Article 59 covers the activities of each supervisory authority.
question: What is the scope of the annual report required by Article 59? reference Article 59 Activity reports, Chapter 6 Independent supervisory authorities

context: Where none of the other supervisory authorities concerned has objected to the draft decision submitted by the lead supervisory authority within the period referred to in paragraphs 4 and 5, the lead supervisory authority and the supervisory authorities concerned shall be deemed to be in agreement with that draft decision and shall be bound by it.
question: What happens if none of the other supervisory authorities concerned objects to the draft decision submitted by the lead supervisory authority? reference Article 60 Cooperation between the lead supervisory authority and the other supervisory authorities concerned, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: Where none of the other supervisory authorities concerned has objected to the draft decision submitted by the lead supervisory authority within the period referred to in paragraphs 4 and 5, the lead supervisory authority and the supervisory authorities concerned shall be deemed to be in agreement with that draft decision and shall be bound by it.

context: No, according to GDPR, requested supervisory authorities shall not charge a fee for any action taken by them pursuant to a request for mutual assistance.

text: No, according to GDPR, requested supervisory authorities shall not charge a fee for any action taken by them pursuant to a request for mutual assistance.

context: The Commission may participate in the consistency mechanism mentioned in Article 63 of GDPR where relevant.
question: What is the role of the Commission in the consistency mechanism mentioned in Article 63 of GDPR? reference Article 63 Consistency mechanism, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

context: Where, in accordance with paragraph 1, staff of a seconding supervisory authority operate in another Member State, the Member State of the host supervisory authority shall assume responsibility for their actions, including liability, for any damage caused by them during their operations, in accordance with the law of the Member State in whose territory they are operating.
question: What happens if staff of a seconding supervisory authority operate in another Member State? reference Article 62 Joint operations of supervisory authorities, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: Where, in accordance with paragraph 1, staff of a seconding supervisory authority operate in another Member State, the Member State of the host supervisory authority shall assume responsibility for their actions, including liability, for any damage caused by them during their operations, in accordance with the law of the Member State in whose territory they are operating.

context: If a member of the Board does not object to the draft decision within a reasonable period indicated by the Chair, the member shall be deemed to be in agreement with the draft decision.

text: If a member of the Board does not object to the draft decision within a reasonable period indicated by the Chair, the member shall be deemed to be in agreement with the draft decision.

context: Yes, any supervisory authority may request an urgent opinion or an urgent binding decision from the Board where a competent supervisory authority has not taken an appropriate measure in a situation where there is an urgent need to act, in order to protect the rights and freedoms of data subjects, giving reasons for requesting such opinion or decision, including for the urgent need to act.
question: Can any supervisory authority request an urgent opinion or an urgent binding decision from the Board? reference Article 66 Urgency procedure, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: Yes, any supervisory authority may request an urgent opinion or an urgent binding decision from the Board where a competent supervisory authority has not taken an appropriate measure in a situation where there is an urgent need to act, in order to protect the rights and freedoms of data subjects, giving reasons for requesting such opinion or decision, including for the urgent need to act.

context: The purpose of the Board referred to in Article 67 of GDPR is to facilitate cooperation between supervisory authorities.
question: What is the purpose of the Board referred to in Article 67 of GDPR? reference Article 67 Exchange of information, Chapter 7 Cooperation and consistency

text: The purpose of the Board referred to in Article 67 of GDPR is to facilitate cooperation between supervisory authorities.

text: The lead supervisory authority or, as the case may be, the supervisory authority with which the complaint has been lodged shall adopt its final decision on the basis of the decision referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article, without undue delay and at the latest by one month after the Board has notified its decision.

text: The assessment shall contain at least: (a) a systematic description of the envisaged processing operations and the purposes of the processing, including, where applicable, the legitimate interest pursued by the controller; (b) an assessment of the necessity and proportionality of the processing operations in relation to the purposes; (c) an assessment of the risks to the rights and freedoms of data subjects referred to in paragraph 1; and (d) the measures envisaged to address the risks, including safeguards, security measures and mechanisms to ensure the protection of personal data and to demonstrate compliance with this Regulation taking into account the rights and legitimate interests of data subjects and other persons concerned.

text: The specific obligations mentioned in Article 95 of GDPR have the same objective set out in Directive 2002/58/EC, which is to ensure the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms, and in particular the right to privacy, with respect to the processing of personal data in the electronic communication sector.

context: Agreements that do not comply with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016 are not covered by Article 96 of GDPR and may be subject to other provisions of GDPR.

text: Agreements that do not comply with Union law as applicable prior to 24 May 2016 are not covered by Article 96 of GDPR and may be subject to other provisions of GDPR.

context: The Commission shall submit a report on the evaluation and review of this Regulation to the European Parliament and to the Council by 25 May 2020 and every four years thereafter.

text: The Commission shall submit a report on the evaluation and review of this Regulation to the European Parliament and to the Council by 25 May 2020 and every four years thereafter.

context: The aim of amending other Union legal acts on data protection is to ensure uniform and consistent protection of natural persons with regard to processing.

text: The aim of amending other Union legal acts on data protection is to ensure uniform and consistent protection of natural persons with regard to processing.

text: For the processing of personal data by the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 applies.

context: Yes, GDPR applies to the processing of personal data by a processor not established in the Union if the processing activities are related to the offering of goods or services to data subjects in the Union or the monitoring of their behavior as far as their behavior takes place within the Union.

text: Yes, GDPR applies to the processing of personal data by a processor not established in the Union if the processing activities are related to the offering of goods or services to data subjects in the Union or the monitoring of their behavior as far as their behavior takes place within the Union.

context: Consent of the data subject means any freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her.

text: Consent of the data subject means any freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her.

context: 'International organisation' means an organisation and its subordinate bodies governed by public international law, or any other body which is set up by, or on the basis of, an agreement between two or more countries.

text: 'International organisation' means an organisation and its subordinate bodies governed by public international law, or any other body which is set up by, or on the basis of, an agreement between two or more countries.

context: Where the lead supervisory authority and the supervisory authorities concerned agree to dismiss or reject parts of a complaint and to act on other parts of that complaint, a separate decision shall be adopted for each of those parts of the matter. The lead supervisory authority shall adopt the decision for the part concerning actions in relation to the controller, shall notify it to the main establishment or single establishment of the controller or processor on the territory of its Member State and shall inform the complainant thereof, while the supervisory authority of the complainant shall adopt the decision for the part concerning dismissal or rejection of that complaint, and shall notify it to that complainant and shall inform the controller or processor thereof.

text: Where the lead supervisory authority and the supervisory authorities concerned agree to dismiss or reject parts of a complaint and to act on other parts of that complaint, a separate decision shall be adopted for each of those parts of the matter. The lead supervisory authority shall adopt the decision for the part concerning actions in relation to the controller, shall notify it to the main establishment or single establishment of the controller or processor on the territory of its Member State and shall inform the complainant thereof, while the supervisory authority of the complainant shall adopt the decision for the part concerning dismissal or rejection of that complaint, and shall notify it to that complainant and shall inform the controller or processor thereof.
