context: When deciding on the amount of an administrative fine in each individual case due regard shall be given to the nature, gravity and duration of the infringement taking into account the nature scope or purpose of the processing concerned as well as the number of data subjects affected and the level of damage suffered by them; the intentional or negligent character of the infringement; any action taken by the controller or processor to mitigate the damage suffered by data subjects; the degree of responsibility of the controller or processor taking into account technical and organisational measures implemented by them pursuant to Articles 25 and 32; any relevant previous infringements by the controller or processor; the degree of cooperation with the supervisory authority, in order to remedy the infringement and mitigate the possible adverse effects of the infringement; the categories of personal data affected by the infringement; the manner in which the infringement became known to the supervisory authority, in particular whether, and if so to what extent, the controller or processor notified the infringement; where measures referred to in Article 58(2) have previously been ordered against the controller or processor concerned with regard to the same subject-matter, compliance with those measures; adherence to approved codes of conduct pursuant to Article 40 or approved certification mechanisms pursuant to Article 42; and any other aggravating or mitigating factor applicable to the circumstances of the case, such as financial benefits gained, or losses avoided, directly or indirectly, from the infringement.
question: What factors should be taken into account when deciding on the amount of an administrative fine according to Article 83?

text: When deciding on the amount of an administrative fine in each individual case due regard shall be given to the nature, gravity and duration of the infringement taking into account the nature scope or purpose of the processing concerned as well as the number of data subjects affected and the level of damage suffered by them; the intentional or negligent character of the infringement; any action taken by the controller or processor to mitigate the damage suffered by data subjects; the degree of responsibility of the controller or processor taking into account technical and organisational measures implemented by them pursuant to Articles 25 and 32; any relevant previous infringements by the controller or processor; the degree of cooperation with the supervisory authority, in order to remedy the infringement and mitigate the possible adverse effects of the infringement; the categories of personal data affected by the infringement; the manner in which the infringement became known to the supervisory authority, in particular whether, and if so to what extent, the controller or processor notified the infringement; where measures referred to in Article 58(2) have previously been ordered against the controller or processor concerned with regard to the same subject-matter, compliance with those measures; adherence to approved codes of conduct pursuant to Article 40 or approved certification mechanisms pursuant to Article 42; and any other aggravating or mitigating factor applicable to the circumstances of the case, such as financial benefits gained, or losses avoided, directly or indirectly, from the infringement.

context: The purpose of the penalties laid down by Member States in accordance with Article 84 of the GDPR is to provide effective, proportionate, and dissuasive penalties for infringements of the GDPR that are not subject to administrative fines under Article 83.
question: What is the purpose of the penalties laid down by Member States in accordance with Article 84 of the GDPR?

text: The purpose of the penalties laid down by Member States in accordance with Article 84 of the GDPR is to provide effective, proportionate, and dissuasive penalties for infringements of the GDPR that are not subject to administrative fines under Article 83.

context: Article 85 of the GDPR Regulation states that Member States shall by law reconcile the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation with the right to freedom of expression and information, including processing for journalistic purposes and the purposes of academic, artistic or literary expression. For processing carried out for journalistic purposes or the purpose of academic artistic or literary expression, Member States shall provide for exemptions or derogations from certain chapters of the Regulation if they are necessary to reconcile the right to the protection of personal data with the freedom of expression and information.
question: What does Article 85 of the GDPR Regulation state regarding the right to freedom of expression and information?

text: Article 85 of the GDPR Regulation states that Member States shall by law reconcile the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation with the right to freedom of expression and information, including processing for journalistic purposes and the purposes of academic, artistic or literary expression. For processing carried out for journalistic purposes or the purpose of academic artistic or literary expression, Member States shall provide for exemptions or derogations from certain chapters of the Regulation if they are necessary to reconcile the right to the protection of personal data with the freedom of expression and information.

context: The rules may pertain to various aspects of employment, including recruitment, performance of the employment contract, management, planning and organization of work, equality and diversity in the workplace, health and safety at work, protection of employer's or customer's property, and the exercise and enjoyment of rights and benefits related to employment, as well as the termination of the employment relationship.
question: What aspects of employment can the rules provided by Member States or collective agreements pertain to according to Article 88?

text: The rules may pertain to various aspects of employment, including recruitment, performance of the employment contract, management, planning and organization of work, equality and diversity in the workplace, health and safety at work, protection of employer's or customer's property, and the exercise and enjoyment of rights and benefits related to employment, as well as the termination of the employment relationship.

context: Member States may further determine the specific conditions for the processing of a national identification number or any other identifier of general application only under appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject pursuant to this Regulation.
question: Under what conditions can Member States determine the specific conditions for the processing of a national identification number or any other identifier of general application?

text: Member States may further determine the specific conditions for the processing of a national identification number or any other identifier of general application only under appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject pursuant to this Regulation.

context: Personal data in official documents held by a public authority or a public body or a private body for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest may be disclosed by the authority or body in accordance with Union or Member State law to which the public authority or body is subject in order to reconcile public access to official documents with the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation.
question: Under what circumstances can personal data in official documents held by a public authority or a public body or a private body be disclosed?

text: Personal data in official documents held by a public authority or a public body or a private body for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest may be disclosed by the authority or body in accordance with Union or Member State law to which the public authority or body is subject in order to reconcile public access to official documents with the right to the protection of personal data pursuant to this Regulation.

context: The conditions and safeguards referred to in paragraph 1 of Article 89, which include appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject and technical and organisational measures to ensure respect for the principle of data minimisation.
question: What are the conditions and safeguards that Union or Member State law may provide for derogations from the rights referred to in Articles 15, 16, 18 and 21 for processing personal data for scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes?

text: The conditions and safeguards referred to in paragraph 1 of Article 89, which include appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of the data subject and technical and organisational measures to ensure respect for the principle of data minimisation.

context: The purpose of the specific rules is to reconcile the right of the protection of personal data with the obligation of secrecy.
question: What is the purpose of the specific rules that Member States may adopt in relation to controllers or processors subject to an obligation of secrecy under Union or Member State law?

text: The purpose of the specific rules is to reconcile the right of the protection of personal data with the obligation of secrecy.

context: Churches and religious associations may continue to apply their existing data protection rules if they are comprehensive and brought into line with the GDPR Regulation.
question: Under what conditions may churches and religious associations continue to apply their existing data protection rules?

text: Churches and religious associations may continue to apply their existing data protection rules if they are comprehensive and brought into line with the GDPR Regulation.

context: The period of time within which the European Parliament or the Council must express objection to a delegated act adopted pursuant to Article 12(8) and Article 43(8) is three months.
question: What is the period of time within which the European Parliament or the Council must express objection to a delegated act adopted pursuant to Article 12(8) and Article 43(8)?

text: The period of time within which the European Parliament or the Council must express objection to a delegated act adopted pursuant to Article 12(8) and Article 43(8) is three months.

context: The committee mentioned in Article 93 is meant to assist the Commission.
question: What is the purpose of the committee mentioned in Article 93?

text: The committee mentioned in Article 93 is meant to assist the Commission.

context: Directive 95/46/EC is repealed with effect from 25 May 2018.
question: When is Directive 95/46/EC repealed?

text: Directive 95/46/EC is repealed with effect from 25 May 2018.

context: No, Article 95 of the GDPR shall not impose additional obligations on natural or legal persons in relation to processing in connection with the provision of publicly available electronic communications services in public communication networks in the Union in relation to matters for which they are subject to specific obligations with the same objective set out in Directive 2002/58/EC.
question: Does Article 95 of the GDPR impose additional obligations on natural or legal persons in relation to processing in connection with the provision of publicly available electronic communications services in public communication networks in the Union?

text: No, Article 95 of the GDPR shall not impose additional obligations on natural or legal persons in relation to processing in connection with the provision of publicly available electronic communications services in public communication networks in the Union in relation to matters for which they are subject to specific obligations with the same objective set out in Directive 2002/58/EC.

context: They shall remain in force until amended, replaced or revoked.
question: According to Article 96, what happens to international agreements involving the transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations that were concluded by Member States prior to May 24, 2016 and comply with Union law as applicable prior to that date?

text: They shall remain in force until amended, replaced or revoked.

context: By 25 May 2020 and every four years thereafter.
question: What is the deadline for the Commission to submit a report on the evaluation and review of this Regulation to the European Parliament and to the Council?

text: By 25 May 2020 and every four years thereafter.

context: The purpose of Article 98 of the GDPR Regulation is to ensure uniform and consistent protection of natural persons with regard to processing by Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies and on the free movement of such data by submitting legislative proposals to amend other Union legal acts on the protection of personal data.
question: What is the purpose of Article 98 of the GDPR Regulation?

text: The purpose of Article 98 of the GDPR Regulation is to ensure uniform and consistent protection of natural persons with regard to processing by Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies and on the free movement of such data by submitting legislative proposals to amend other Union legal acts on the protection of personal data.

context: The Regulation enters into force on the twentieth day following its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union and applies from 25 May 2018.
question: When does this Regulation enter into force and when does it apply?

text: The Regulation enters into force on the twentieth day following its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union and applies from 25 May 2018.
